      19
      Supramolecular Arrays Based on Dimetal Building Units
      Cotton, F. Albert; Lin, Chun; Murillo, Carlos A.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (10), 759-771CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review with refs. Supramol. chem. is today a major thrust area, a significant part of which is based on the use of metal atoms or ions as key elements in promoting the assembly of and dictating the main structural features of the supramol. products. Most of the work was done with single metal atoms or ions in this role, but considerable success has already been achieved by employing M-M bonded dimetal entities instead. The authors review here the work done in their lab. Metal-metal bonded cationic complexes of the [M2(DAniF)n(MeCN)8-2n](4-n)+ type, where M = Mo or Rh and DAniF is an N,N'-di-p-anisylformamidinate anion, were used as subunit precursors and then linked by various equatorial and axial bridging groups such as polycarboxylate anions, polypyridyls, and polynitriles. Characterization of the products by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, CV, DPV, NMR, and other spectroscopic techniques revealed discrete tetranuclear (pairs or loops), hexanuclear (triangles), octanuclear (squares), and dodecanuclear (cages) species and one-, two-, or three-dimensional mol. nanotubes. These compds. display a rich electrochem. behavior which is affected by the nature of the linkers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXlvFCrsLc%253D&md5=92c4e19e3eee08140954294be52bef23

      Kim, J.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T. M.; Li, H.; Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; O'Keefe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2001, 123, 8239.
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      Assembly of Metal-Organic Frameworks from Large Organic and Inorganic Secondary Building Units: New Examples and Simplifying Principles for Complex Structures
      Kim, Jaheon; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (34), 8239-8247CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The secondary building unit (SBU) was identified as a useful tool in the anal. of complex metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The authors illustrate its applicability to rationalizing MOF crystal structures by anal. of nine new MOFs which were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Tetrahedral SBUs in Zn(ADC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-31; H2ADC = acetylenedicarboxylic acid; HTEA = monoprotonated triethylamine), Cd(ATC)·[Cd(H2O)6](H2O)5 (MOF-32; H4ATC = adamantanetetracarboxylic acid), and Zn2(ATB)(H2O)·(H2O)3(DMF)3 (MOF-33; H4ATB = adamantanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into diamond networks, while those of Ni2(ATC)(H2O)4·(H2O)4 (MOF-34) have the structure of the Al network in SrAl2. Frameworks constructed from less sym. tetrahedral SBUs have the Ga network of CaGa2O4 as illustrated by Zn2(ATC)·(EtOH)2(H2O)2 (MOF-35) structure. Squares and tetrahedral SBUs in Zn2(MTB)(H2O)2·(DMF)6(H2O)5 (MOF-36; H4MTB = methanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into the PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of these shapes. The octahedral SBUs found in Zn2(NDC)3·[(HTEA)(DEF)(ClBz)]2 (MOF-37; H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) form the most common structure for linking octahedral shapes, namely, the B network in CaB6. New structure types for linking triangular and trigonal prismatic SBUs are found in Zn3O(BTC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-38; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Zn3O(HBTB)2(H2O)·(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (MOF-39; H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid). The synthesis, crystal structure, and structure anal. using the SBU approach are presented for each MOF.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXls1Okt7w%253D&md5=b62be98fb09b7b7995390315da27c217

      A three-dimensional homometallic molecular ferrimagnet
      Konar, Sanjit; Mukherjee, Partha Sarathi; Zangrando, Ennio; Lloret, Francesc; Chaudhuri, Nirmalendu Ray
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (9), 1561-1563CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      Chains of fused NiII octahedral units form a 3-dimensional network and thereby the 1st example of a homometallic 3-dimensional ferrimagnet. [Ni3(fum)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]n (H2fum = fumaric acid) was prepd. from Na2fum and Ni(NO3)2 and characterized by x-ray anal. and a low-temp. magnetic study. The complex is monoclinic, space group P21/c, Z = 2, R = 0.0508, wR2 = 0.1383. The structure features an infinite - Ni-(μ3-OH)-Ni2- chain and the spin of adjacent Ni centers alternates between S = 1 and S = 2 (see picture).

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XjvVGlu7w%253D&md5=12793463727097a3f711291c46d037ca

      (a) Kurmoo, M.; Kumagai, H.; Green, M. A.; Lovett, B. W.; Blundell, S. J.; Ardavan, A.; Singleton, J. J. Solid State Chem.2001, 159, 343.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Two Modifications of Layered Cobaltous Terephthalate: Crystal Structures and Magnetic Properties
      Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Kumagai, Hitoshi; Green, Mark A.; Lovett, Brendon W.; Blundell, Stephen J.; Ardavan, Arzhang; Singleton, John
      Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2001), 159 (2), 343-351CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Academic Press)
      The synthesis, characterization, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of Co2(OH)2BDC and Co(H2O)2BDC (BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate or terephthalate, O2CC6H4CO2) are reported. Co2(OH)2BDC (space group C2/m, a 19.952, b 3.286, c 6.295 Å, β 95.84°, Z = 2) consists of two types of edge-sharing CoO6 chains that are connected to each other by OH (Co-O-Co bridges) to form layers that are further joined together through terephthalate. It exhibits unusual magnetic properties: >48 K it displays paramagnetism, between 44 and 48 K it behaves as a collinear antiferromagnet, and <44 K a weak spontaneous magnetization is obsd. in very low applied fields. At higher fields metamagnetic behavior is obsd. Two types of hysteresis loops are obsd., one centered about zero field and the 2nd about the metamagnetic crit. field. The crit. field and the hysteresis width increase as the temp. is lowered; the latter exceeds 50 kOe at 2 K The unusual large coercivity may be due to the large single-ion anisotropy of Co(II) and its pronounced increase at low temp. Co(H2O)2BDC (space group C2/c, a 18.274, b 6.543, c 7.296 Å, β 98.6°, Z = 4) consists of layers of sepd. octahedral CoO6 connected via Co-O-C-O-Co. It is paramagnetic and obeys the Curie-Weiss law (Θ=-27 K). (c) 2001 Academic Press.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXkvVWnt7w%253D&md5=0c3bf42f5bd42ba32cc8098004fae1a2
      (b) Kurmoo, M. Philos. Trans. R. Soc., A1999, 357, 3041.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Ferrimagnetic and metamagnetic layered cobalt(II)-hydroxides: first observation of a coercive field greater than 5 T
      Kurmoo, M.
      Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, Series A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences (1999), 357 (1762), 3041-3061CODEN: PTRMAD; ISSN:1364-503X. (Royal Society)
      The synthesis, characterization by XRD, UV-visible, IR and TGA and the magnetic properties of four layered compds., 1, Co5(OH)8(H2O)2(NO3)2; 2, Co5(OH)8(O2CC6H4CO2)·2H2O; 3, Co2(OH)3(NO3); 4, Co4(OH)2(O2CC6H4CO2)3·(NH 3)1.5(H2O)2.5, are reported. 1 And 2 were characterized by triple-deck layers consisting of both octahedral and tetrahedral cobaltous ions and 3 and 4 contain single-deck layers of only octahedral cobaltous ions. 1 And 2 behave as ferrimagnets which were characterized by a min. in the χT vs. T plot, spontaneous magnetization, imaginary AC-susceptibility and hysteresis loop. The Curie temp. are 30 and 40 K and the coercive fields at 4.2 K are 850 and 1750 Oe, resp. 3 And 4 behave as metamagnets which were characterized by maxima in the susceptibility at the Neel temp. of 10 and 38 K, resp., and by a crit. field (antiferromagnetic ↔ paramagnetic) of ca. 1 KOe for 3 at 4.5 K and >50 kOe for 4 at 2 K. The tricrit. temp., sepg. the region of reversible and nonreversible M vs. H, for 4 is established at 22.5 K. The long-range magnetic ordering for the two structural types is discussed from dipolar interactions between layers. The intralayer interactions are ferromagnetic in all cases whereas the interlayer interactions are ferromagnetic for 1 and 2 and antiferromagnetic for 3 and 4. The Curie or Neel temp. is weakly dependent on the interlayer distance and its observation does not depend on the existence of covalent bonds between the layers. The large coercive fields obsd. are due to the alignment of the moments perpendicular to the layers and the synergy between cryst. shape and single-ion anisotropies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXktVejtg%253D%253D&md5=29c6ff300e46f012505f472c27c4f2e8

      Infinite secondary building units and forbidden catenation in metal-organic framework
      Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (2), 284-287CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      The metal-org. framework compds. MOF-69A, [Zn3(OH)2(bpdc)2]·4DEF·2H2O (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; DEF = N,N-diethylformamide), and MOF-69B, [Zn3(OH)2(ndc)2]·4DEF·2H2O (ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate), were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. Both MOF-69A and MOF-69B have three-dimensional structures constructed from infinite Zn-O-C secondary building units, which provide a framework in which catenation is forbidden. Both compds. contain one-dimensional rhombic channels in which the DEF and water mols. reside as guests. MOF-69A and MOF-69B are stable to exchange of guests in soln., and the process is fully reversible.

      Neutron diffraction measurements on brucite
      Zigan, F.; Rothbauer, R.
      Neues Jahrbuch fuer Mineralogie, Monatshefte (1967), (4-5), 137-43CODEN: NJMMAW; ISSN:0028-3649.
      Neutron diffraction measurements on brucite, Mg(OH)2, both powder and single crystal, confirm its space group and lattice parameters. The O-H distance is 0.995 ± 0.008 A.; unit cell dimensions a 3.142 ± 0.001, b 4.766 ± 0.002 A. The isotypy of Ca(OH)2 was also confirmed with respect to the H positions. The thermal vibration of the H nucleus is strongly anisotropic with max. elongation transverse to the O-H bond direction. Deuterated brucite, Mg(OD)2, was also examd. 15 references.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2sXltVentLY%253D&md5=78b28f427e25e3f70d954562529d7312
    26. 26
      (a) Steiner, T. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2002, 41, 48.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      26
      Reviews: The hydrogen bond in the solid state
      Steiner, Thomas
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (1), 48-76CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      A review. The hydrogen bond is the most important of all directional intermol. interactions. It is operative in detg. mol. conformation, mol. aggregation, and the function of a vast no. of chem. systems ranging from inorg. to biol. Research into hydrogen bonds experienced a stagnant period in the 1980s but re-opened around 1990, and has been in rapid development since then. In terms of modern concepts, the hydrogen bond is understood as a very broad phenomenon, and it is accepted that there are open borders to other effects. There are dozens of different types of X-H···A hydrogen bonds that occur commonly in the condensed phases, and in addn. there are innumerable less common ones. Dissocn. energies span more than two orders of magnitude (about 02.-40 kcal mol-1). Within this range, the nature of the interaction is not const., but its electrostatic, covalent, and dispersion contributions vary in their relative wts. The hydrogen bond has broad transition regions that merge continuously with the covalent bond, the van der Waals interaction, the ionic interaction, and also the cation-π interaction. All hydrogen bonds can be considered as incipient proton transfer reactions, and for strong hydrogen bonds, this reaction can be in a very advanced state. In this review, a coherent survey is given on all these matters.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvFWguw%253D%253D&md5=9ec459e4c0b6204edceac7337858e6e1
      (b) Desiraju, G. R. Chem. Commun. 2005, 2995 and references therein.
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      27
      The crystal structure of manganese(II) succinate tetrahydrate
      Gupta, M. P.; Sahu, R. D.; Ram, Raja; Maulik, P. R.
      Zeitschrift fuer Kristallographie (1983), 163 (1-2), 155-8CODEN: ZEKRDZ; ISSN:0044-2968.
      The title crystals are triclinic, space group P‾1, with a 5.50(1), b 9.05(2), c 5.26(1) Å, α 96.1(5), β 98.9(5), and γ 120.5(5)°; Z = 1. The structure was solved by the heavy-atom method and refined to a final R of 0.11 for all the 501 reflections. The Mn2+ ion is coordinated with 6 O atoms at distances of 2.18-2.24 Å. Both the carboxyl groups in the succinate anion are twisted out of the plane of the 4 C atoms by 7.7°. At. coordinates are given.

      Crystal structure of catena-tetraaquasuccinato-O,O'-cobalt(II), Co(C4H4O4)(H2O)4
      Zheng, Y.-Q.; Lin, J.-L.
      Zeitschrift fuer Kristallographie - New Crystal Structures (2000), 215 (1), 159-160CODEN: ZKNSFT; ISSN:1433-7266. (R. Oldenbourg Verlag)
      The title compd. is monoclinic, space group P21/c, a 7.397(4), b 14.792(5), c 7.775(4) Å, β 99.73°, Z = 4, R = 0.042, Rw = 0.111 for 1364 reflections with I0 > 2σ(Io). At. coordinates are given. The compd. is isostructural with the corresponding Ni complex. The Co atom is octahedrally coordinated by 2 O atoms of 2 bridging OOCCH2-CH2-COO anions in the trans position and 4 O atoms from H2O mols. Chains of ∞1[co(H2O)(C4H4O4)2/2] run parallel [10‾1] and are held together by H bonds.

      Crystal structure of tetraaquaglutaratomanganese(II), Mn(C5H6O4)(H2O)4

      Zeitschrift fuer Kristallographie - New Crystal Structures (2000), 215 (1), 163-164CODEN: ZKNSFT; ISSN:1433-7266. (R. Oldenbourg Verlag)
      The title compd. is monoclinic, space group C2/c, a 13.196(3), b 7.139(1), c 21.793(4) Å, β 107.03(3)°, Z = 8, R = 0.029, Rw = 0.075 for 1896 reflections with Io > 2σ(Io). At. coordinates are given. The crystal structure is composed of ∞1[Mn(H2O)4(C5H6O4)2/2] chains linked together by H bonds. The Mn atom is octahedrally coordinated by 6 O atoms; the ones in the cis position belong to 2 different dicarboxylate anions, while the remaining 4 O atoms belong to different H2O mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXns1amtA%253D%253D&md5=3e192f73445c86244eebec9a15a938ed
      (e) Suresh, E.; Bhadbhade, M. M.; Venkatasubramanian, K. Polyhedron1999, 18, 657.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      27
      Metal α,ω dicarboxylate complexes. 4. Effect of N-donor substitutions on the polymeric network in cobalt(II) hexanedioate complexes: synthesis and single crystal X-ray investigations
      Suresh, E.; Bhadbhade, M. M.; Venkatasubramanian, K.
      Polyhedron (1999), 18 (5), 657-667CODEN: PLYHDE; ISSN:0277-5387. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      Three Co(II) hexanedioate complexes [Co(H2O)4L]n 1 (H2L = hexanedioic acid), [Co(imidazole)4L]n 2 and [Co(pyridine)2(H2O)4]L 3 were synthesized and structurally characterized to study the effect of N-donor substituents coordinated to the metal center on the polymeric network. Complex 1 is an extended linear polymer; Co(H2O)4 units are linked by the monodentate carboxylate from either end of the extended deprotonated hexanedioic acid. There are intra- and interchain H-bonding interactions between the coordinated H2O mols. and the end carboxylate O atoms, the uncoordinated O atom creates two dimensional H bonding pattern. Complex 2 also is a linear polymer; Co(imidazole)4 units are linked by monodentate dibasic acid at the either end but with S shaped conformation of the hexanedioic acid, not as fully extended as in 1. The effect of bulkier N-donor substitution is seen in the distortion of the octahedral coordination polyhedron of Co(II). The noncoordinated carboxylate O makes one intra and one interchain H-bonding interaction with the imidazole N-H group making a two-dimensional H-bonded network as in 1. In 3 with the two strong N-donor pyridines coordinated to the metal center, the hexanedioate is out of the coordination sphere and acts as a counterion. The Co(pyridine)2(H2O)4 units are linked by H-bonding in both the dimensions by extensively folded adipate dianion forming a sheet structure parallel to ab plane. This is the 1st example showing a strong H-bonding network in which a tetraaquacobalt(II) center forms an eight-membered ring with bidentate H-bonding interactions. None of the coordination polymeric structures form any channels in their mol. packing, even to include a small entity as a H2O mol.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXjtFSgu7w%253D&md5=87674e9e31deb21a060043c9ed143e6d
      (f) Sun, D.; Cao, R.; Liang, Y.; Shi, Q.; Su, W.; Hong, M. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans.2001, 2335.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      27
      Hydrothermal syntheses, structures and properties of terephthalate-bridged polymeric complexes with zig-zag chain and channel structures
      Sun, Daofeng; Cao, Rong; Liang, Yucang; Shi, Qian; Su, Weiping; Hong, Maochun
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions (2001), (16), 2335-2340CODEN: JCSDAA; ISSN:1472-7773. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Hydrothermal reactions of 1,4-dicyanobenzene, phen and M(OAc)2 (M = Co, Zn) or MCl2 (M = Cu, Mn, Cd) gave rise to the hydrolysis of 1,4-dicyanobenzene into terephthalic acid and the formation of five polymeric complexes [M(ta)(phen)(H2O)]n (M = Co, 1; Zn, 3), [Cu(ta)(phen)]n (2), [Mn(ta)(phen)]n (4), [Cd(ta)1/2(phen)Cl]n (5) (ta = terephthalate, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline). Crystal structure analyses revealed that complexes 1-3 have one-dimensional zigzag chain structures, and 4 and 5 possess three-dimensional network structures with channels. Magnetic susceptibility measurements for 1, 2 and 4 were consistent with the occurrence of weak antiferromagnetic interaction through the ta bridge.

      32
      A Single-Chain Magnet Formed by a Twisted Arrangement of Ions with Easy-Plane Magnetic Anisotropy
      Kajiwara, Takashi; Nakano, Motohiro; Kaneko, Yukihiro; Takaishi, Shinya; Ito, Tasuku; Yamashita, Masahiro; Igashira-Kamiyama, Asako; Nojiri, Hiroyuki; Ono, Yuuki; Kojima, Norimichi
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (29), 10150-10151CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A unique single-chain quantum magnet was formed by an alternating arrangement of high-spin FeII/low-spin FeIII ions in catena-Fe(ClO4)2{Fe(bis(2-pyridylcarbonyl)amine)2}ClO4.3MeNO2. Crystallog. data and at. coordinates are given. Although the predominant spin-carrier components (high-spin FeII) possess easy-plane magnetic anisotropy (D > 0), twisted arrangement of easy-planes along the chain axis defines a novel class of 1-dimensional Ising system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXlvVaisr4%253D&md5=26a314f62f8f6f4aef66beb0e04e7fb0
      (c) Ferbinteanu, M.; Miyasaka, H.; Wernsdorfer, W.; Nakata, K.; Sugiura, K.-i.; Yamashita, M.; Coulon, C.; Clérac, R. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2005, 127, 3090.
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      Single-Chain Magnet (NEt4)[Mn2(5-MeOsalen)2Fe(CN)6] Made of MnIII-FeIII-MnIII Trinuclear Single-Molecule Magnet with an ST = 9/2 Spin Ground State
      Ferbinteanu, Marilena; Miyasaka, Hitoshi; Wernsdorfer, Wolfgang; Nakata, Kazuya; Sugiura, Ken-ichi; Yamashita, Masahiro; Coulon, Claude; Clerac, Rodolphe
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (9), 3090-3099CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The cyano-bridged trinuclear compd., (NEt4)[Mn2(salmen)2(MeOH)2Fe(CN)6] (1) (salmen2- = rac-N,N'-(1-methylethylene)bis(salicylideneiminate)), reported previously by Miyasaka et al. (1988) was restudied using combined a.c. and d.c. susceptibility measurements. The strong frequency dependence of the a.c. susceptibility and the slow relaxation of the magnetization show that 1 behaves as a single-mol. magnet with an ST = 9/2 spin ground state. Its relaxation time (τ) follows an Arrhenius law with τ0 = 2.5 × 10-7 s and Δeff/kB = 14 K. Also, <0.3 K, τ sats. around 470 s, indicating that quantum tunneling of the magnetization becomes the dominant process of relaxation. (NEt4)[Mn2(5-MeOsalen)2Fe(CN)6] (2) (5-MeOsalen2- = N,N'-ethylenebis(5-methoxysalicylideneiminate)) is a heterometallic 1-dimensional assembly made of the trinuclear [MnIII(SB)-NC-FeIII-CN-MnIII(SB)] (SB is a salen-type Schiff-base ligand) motif similar to 1. Compd. 2 has two types of bridges, a cyano bridge (-NC-) and a biphenolate bridge (-(O)2-), connecting MnIII and FeIII ions and the two MnIII ions, resp. Both bridges mediate ferromagnetic interactions, as shown by modeling the magnetic susceptibility >10 K with gav = 2.03, JMn-Fe/kB = +6.5 K, and J'/kB = +0.07 K, where J' is the exchange coupling between the trimer units. The d.c. magnetic measurements of a single crystal using micro-SQUID and Hall-probe magnetometers revealed a uniaxial anisotropy (DT/kB = -0.94 K) with an easy axis lying along the chain direction. Frequency dependence of the a.c. susceptibility and time dependence of the d.c. magnetization were performed to study the slow relaxation of the magnetization. A mean relaxation time was found, and its temp. dependence was studied. Above 1.4 K, both magnetic susceptibility and relaxation time are in agreement with the dynamics described in the 1960s by R. J. Glauber for 1-dimensional systems with ferromagnetically coupled Ising spins (τ0 = 3.7 × 10-10 s and Δ1/kB = 31 K). As expected, at lower temps. <1.4 K, the relaxation process is dominated by the finite-size chain effects (τ'0 = 3 × 10-8 s and Δ2/kB = 25 K). The detailed anal. of this single-chain magnet behavior and its two regimes is consistent with magnetic parameters independently estd. (J' and DT) and allows the detn. of the av. chain length of 60 nm (or 44 trimer units). Crystallog. data are given for compd. 2. This work illustrates nicely a new strategy to design single-chain magnets by coupling ferromagnetically single-mol. magnets in one dimension.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1OqtL0%253D&md5=e18f5344823e61883691a748150dba0d
      (d) Bogani, L.; Sangregorio, R.; Sessoli, R.; Gatteschi, D. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2005, 44, 5817.
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Molecular engineering for single-chain-magnet behavior in a one-dimensional dysprosium-nitronyl nitroxide compound
      Bogani, Lapo; Sangregorio, Claudio; Sessoli, Roberta; Gatteschi, Dante
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (36), 5817-5821CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A rational approach to decrease magnetic dipolar interactions led to the chain compd. [Dy(hfac)3{NIT(C6H4OPh)}], where NIT(R) is 2-(4'-R)-4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazoline-1-oxyl-3-oxide), the first rare-earth-radical-based single-chain magnet. The compd. shows slow relaxation behavior, a dynamical crossover resulting from finite-size effects, and a very rich static magnetic behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Quantum tunneling of magnetization and related phenomena in molecular materials
      Gatteschi, Dante; Sessoli, Roberta
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (3), 268-297CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review is given on quantum size effects in mol. magnets. The main topics treated are: quantum tunneling and quantum coherence, magnetic relaxation in systems with a large spin, and spin tunneling without and in the presence of an external magnetic field. Emphasis was laid on 2 families of cluster compds. known as the Mn12ac and the Fe8 compds.

      33
      Superexchange interaction and symmetry properties of electron orbitals
      Kanamori, J.
      Physics and Chemistry of Solids (1959), 10 (), 87-98CODEN: PCSOA7; ISSN:0369-8726.
      The relation between the symmetry of electron orbitals and superexchange interaction is discussed. It is shown that the sign of the superexchange interaction is closely connected with the cation orbital state, when the cation is subject to the cryst. field arising from octahedrally or tetrahedrally surrounding anions. In some cases, the sign of the superexchange interaction is definitely detd. from the symmetry relations.

      A Three-Dimensional Coordination Polymer Featuring Effective Ferrimagnetic Hydroxide-Bridged Manganese(II) Chains
      Li, Jin-Tang; Tao, Jun; Huang, Rong-Bin; Zheng, Lan-Sun; Tan, Yuen; Lin, C. L.; Varughese, Princy; Li, Jing
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (13), 4448-4450CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A three-dimensional coordination polymer, [Mn3(OH)2Na2(3-cnba)6]n (1) (3-Hcnba = 3-cyanobenzoic acid), was synthesized by the reaction of MnCl2, NaN3, and 3-Hcnba in H2O. Its crystal structure was detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Magnetic studies show that the complex behaves as a three-dimensional metamagnet built from effective ferrimagnetic Mn(II) chains in which spin moments are linked by interactions in an AF-F-AF (F = ferromagnetic and AF = antiferromagnetic) sequence in the triangular magnetic repeating unit.

      36
      Low dimensional magnetic systems
      Katsumata, K.
      High Magnetic Fields (2003), 2 (), 171-193CODEN: 69EXS8 ISSN:. (World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.)
      A review. Recent progress in lower dimensional magnetism is reviewed, esp. the physics relevant to high magnetic fields. The behavior of several 1D and Q1D antiferromagnetic systems is discussed, including a spin (S) 1 Haldane material, an S = 1 Q1D antiferromagnet with bond alternation, the spin-Peierls system CuGeO3 as well as spin ladder compds. All these systems have a singlet ground state of quantum origin and an energy gap to the lowest excited state. On application of an external magnetic field, these systems exhibit a transition from the non-magnetic to a magnetized state, and in some cases long-range magnetic ordering occurs. Efforts are made to explain the underlying physics intuitively at the expense of rigor.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXovFeg&md5=34ffc9bbdcc6ea613f30af52080f3c4f
      (b) Yamashita, M.; Ishii, T.; Matsuzaka, M. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2000, 198, 347.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      36
      Haldane gap systems
      Yamashita, M.; Ishii, T.; Matsuzaka, H.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2000), 198 (), 347-366CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science S.A.)
      A review with 44 refs. Haldane gap compds. with S = 1 formulated as [Ni(AA)2X]Y ((AA)2 = (diamines)2, linear tetramines, N4-macrocycles; X = NO2 and N3; Y = ClO4, BF4, and PF6) and Me4N[Ni(NO2)3], and with S = 2 formulated as [Mn(AA)2Cl3] (AA = bipy and phen) are described. They have 1D structures with bridging ligands. The Haldane conjecture was proven by magnetic susceptibility and high-field magnetization measurements. The magnitudes of the Haldane gap with S = 1 can be controlled by combination of the bridging ligands, in-plane ligands, and counteranions as follows: X, N3 > NO2; AA, en ≥ tn > linear tetramines > dmpn > Me6[14]aneN4 ≥ [15]aneN4; Y, ClO4 > PF6. In spite of a similar structure to Haldane gap compds., the [Ni([15]aneN4)N3]PF6 and [Ni(en)2(NO2)]BF4 species show spin-glass behavior, which is very novel in 1D spin systems. The [Mn(bipy)Cl3] is regarded as the 1st example of the Haldane gap system with S = 2.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXislegu78%253D&md5=e209f54c82056c8888d4f8c998e8eaea
      (c) Katsumata, K. J. Magn.Magn. Mater. 1995, 140, 1595.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Experimental studies of one-dimensional quantum spin systems
      Katsumata, K.
      Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials (1995), 140-144 (Pt. 3), 1595-8CODEN: JMMMDC; ISSN:0304-8853. (Elsevier)
      A review with 32 refs. The authors review the exptl. results on a spin (S) one, 1-dimensional Heisenberg antiferromagnet (1DHA). In particular, how has the existence of the Haldane gap been confirmed and what is the nature of the ground state, are discussed. In the latter part of this paper, the authors' recent expts. on S = 2 1DHA and 1-dimensional antiferromagnets with competing exchange interactions are reported.

      37
      Randomness-driven quantum phase transition in bond-alternating haldane chain
      Arakawa, Takayuki; Todo, Synge; Takayama, Hajime
      Journal of the Physical Society of Japan (2005), 74 (4), 1127-1130CODEN: JUPSAU; ISSN:0031-9015. (Physical Society of Japan)
      The effect of bond randomness on the spin-gapped ground state of the spin-1 bond-alternating antiferromagnetic Heisenberg chain is discussed. By using the loop cluster quantum Monte Carlo method, the authors study the stability of topol. order in terms of the recently proposed twist order parameter [M. Nakamura and S. Todo: Phys. Rev. Lett. 89(2002) 077204]. The dimer phases as well as the Haldane phase of the spin-1 Heisenberg chain are robust against a weak randomness, though the valence-bond-solid-like topol. order in the latter phase is destroyed by introducing a disorder stronger than the crit. value.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXkvF2isbc%253D&md5=333e52266d1b8441fd00a5e654097712

      38
      Ordered porous materials for emerging applications
      Davis, Mark E.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2002), 417 (6891), 813-821CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. "Space,the final frontier. "This preamble to a well-known television series captures the challenge encountered not only in space travel adventures, but also in the field of porous materials, which aims to control the size, shape and uniformity of the porous space and the atoms and mols. that define it. The past decade has seen significant advances in the ability to fabricate new porous solids with ordered structures from a wide range of different materials. This has resulted in materials with unusual properties and broadened their application range beyond the traditional use as catalysts and adsorbents. In fact, porous materials now seem set to contribute to developments in areas ranging from microelectronics to medical diagnosis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xks1Wmurs%253D&md5=1ca631c09ad2fb56a65325f163f265aa

      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      Triblock copolymer syntheses of mesoporous silica with periodic 50 to 300 angstrom pores
      Zhao, Dongyuan; Feng, Jianglin; Huo, Qisheng; Melosh, Nicholas; Frederickson, Glenn H.; Chmelka, Bradley F.; Stucky, Galen D.
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (1998), 279 (5350), 548-552CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Use of amphiphilic triblock copolymers to direct the organization of polymg. silica species has resulted in the prepn. of well-ordered hexagonal mesoporous silica structures (SBA-15) with uniform pore sizes up to approx. 300 angstroms. The SBA-15 materials are synthesized in acidic media to produce highly ordered, two-dimensional hexagonal (space group p6mm) silica-block copolymer mesophases. Calcination at 500°C gives porous structures with unusually large interlattice d spacings of 74.5 to 320 angstroms between the (100) planes, pore sizes from 46 to 300 angstroms, pore vol. fractions up to 0.85, and silica wall thicknesses of 31 to 64 angstroms. SBA-15 can be readily prepd. over a wide range of uniform pore sizes and pore wall thicknesses at low temp. (35° to 80°C), using a variety of poly(alkylene oxide) triblock copolymers and by the addn. of cosolvent org. mols. The block copolymer species can be recovered for reuse by solvent extn. with ethanol or removed by heating at 140°C for 3 h, in both cases, yielding a product that is thermally stable in boiling water.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXotVOitQ%253D%253D&md5=d721e947654c917a222db2dab937c0d4
      (d) Hare, D. O.; Walton, R. I.; Smith, R. I. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2001, 48, 79.
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (e) Lewis, D. W.; Sankar, G.; Wyles, J. K.; Thomas, J. M.; Catlow, C. R. A.; Willock, D. J. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl.1997, 36, 2675.
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      Synthesis of a small-pore microporous material using a computationally designed template
      Lewis, Dewi W.; Sankar, Gopinathan; Wyles, Joanna K.; Thomas, John Meurig; Catlow, C. Richard A.; Willock, David J.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English (1997), 36 (23), 2675-2677CODEN: ACIEAY; ISSN:0570-0833. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      The authors demonstrated the successful application of computer aided materials design, through the identification of crit. parameters in the synthesis and the computational design of a suitable template, to the formation of a microporous material possessing predefined structural and phys. properties, namely an aluminophosphate based material with the CHA structure. Thus, zeolitic DAF-5 was prepd. from a gel with a typical compn. of 0.2CoO:0.9Al2O3:1.5P2O5:30H2O.2L (L = 4-piperidinopiperidine) in a stainless steel autoclave at 150-165° for < 6 h. DAF-5 is hexagonal, a 13.537 and c 15.480 Å and is similar to the mineral chabazite and other related chabazite materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXjtVGrsQ%253D%253D&md5=fed153726fa51bfa51b7ce319b323a3d

        1
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktFShtLk%253D&md5=9df52e99bad3cc0db67f65551a8c154f

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Modular Chemistry: Secondary Building Units as a Basis for the Design of Highly Porous and Robust Metal-Organic Carboxylate Frameworks
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; Li, Hailian; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (4), 319-330CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFymsL0%253D&md5=e3df2f7492090aee280676f044e3b7af
        (d) Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, S.; Vaidyanathan, R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2004, 43, 1466.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Metal carboxylates with open architectures
        Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, Srinivasan; Vaidhyanathan, R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (12), 1466-1496CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. The field of inorg. open-framework materials is dominated by aluminosilicates and phosphates. The metal carboxylates have emerged as an important family in the last few years. This family includes not only mono- and dicarboxylates of transition, rare-earth, and main-group metals, but also a variety of hybrid structures. Some of the carboxylates possess novel adsorption and magnetic properties. Dicarboxylates and related species provide an effective means of designing novel hybrid structures with porous and other properties. In some of these structures, the dicarboxylate acts as a linker between two inorg. units. Hybrid nanocomposites are also of particular note, for example, cadmium oxalate host lattices that can accommodate extended alkali-metal halide structures. This review discusses the synthesis, structure, and properties of various types of open-framework metal carboxylates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXisl2hsbo%253D&md5=32807fb667da7932d3bd2ace7e18f208
        (e) Moulton, B.; Zaworotko, M. J.; Chem. Rev.2001, 101, 1658.
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

        (f) Bradshaw, D.; Claridge, J. B.; Cussen, E. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J. Acc. Chem. Res. 2005, 38, 273.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Design, Chirality, and Flexibility in Nanoporous Molecule-Based Materials
        Bradshaw, D.; Claridge, J. B.; Cussen, E. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (4), 273-282CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Scientific and technol. interest in porous materials with mol.-sized channels and cavities has led to an intense search for controlled chem. routes to systems with specific properties. This Account details our work on directing the assembly of open-framework structures based on mols. and investigating how the response of nanoporous examples of such materials to guests differs from classical rigid porous systems. The stabilization of chiral nanoporosity by a hierarchy of interactions that both direct and maintain a helical open-framework structure exemplifies the approach.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhs1Skuw%253D%253D&md5=c26956fea0067e2d18b4e510bbfc2f34
        (g) Cheetham, A. K.; Ferey, G.; Loiseau, T. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.1999, 38, 3268.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Open-framework inorganic materials
        Cheetham, Anthony K.; Ferey, Gerard; Loiseau, Thierry
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1999), 38 (22), 3268-3292CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A review, with >256 refs., is given on the field of open-framework inorg. materials, on which has expanded dramatically during the last decade. The scope of such materials is no longer limited to aluminosilicate zeolites, Al phosphates and related systems, but now embraces frameworks based upon as many as 25 elements of the periodic table. These include a large no. of main block phosphates, such as those of Ga, In, and Sn, as well as several transition metal phosphates, including systems based upon V, Mo, Co, and Fe. In addn. to oxide-contg. phases, open frameworks are now being found in the realm of sulfides, chlorides, and nitrides, as well as in coordination compds. Applications of open-framework materials continue to be dominated by the aluminosilicate zeolites, which are noted for their stability and which find utility in catalysis, sepns., and ion-exchange, but attempts are being made to exploit some of the exciting properties of the newly discovered systems. The review discusses the synthesis and structures of this growing class of materials, as well as some of their properties and applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXns1yksbo%253D&md5=3ae2e42e9140e41ccf09e03b181dbd25
        (h) Harrison, W. T. A. Curr. Opin. Solid State Mater.2002, 6, 407.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Templated inorganic networks: recent developments
        Harrison, William T. A.
        Current Opinion in Solid State & Materials Science (2002), 6 (5), 407-413CODEN: COSSFX; ISSN:1359-0286. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review on the synthesis of unusual open-framework phases, focusing on inorg. frameworks, i.e., those contg. fused networks of metal-centered polyhedra and oxo-anions. Work from the last year or two only is covered.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Materials: From "Simple" Coordination Polymers to Organodiamine-Templated Molybdenum Oxides
        Hagrman; Hagrman; Zubieta
        Angewandte Chemie (International ed. in English) (1999), 38 (18), 2638-2684 ISSN:.
        A blueprint for the design of oxide materials is provided by nature. By borrowing from nature's ability to influence inorganic microstructures in biomineralization processes and in the hydrothermal synthesis of complex minerals, a new class of materials in which organic components exert a role in controlling inorganic microstructure is evolving. By employing members of the ever-expanding class of polymeric coordination complex cations, novel molybdenum oxide substructures, such as the one shown, may be prepared.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2sbgvFChuw%253D%253D&md5=9bbfa125daa7e95d7c9bede5c8adea66
        (j) Maschmeyer, T.; Rey, F.; Sankar, G.; Thomas, J. M. Nature1995, 378, 159.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Heterogeneous catalysts obtained by grafting metallocene complexes onto mesoporous silica
        Maschmeyer, Thomas; Rey, Fernando; Sankar, Gopinathan; Thomas, John Meurig
        Nature (London) (1995), 378 (6553), 159-62CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        The synthesis of mesoporous siliceous solids with large-diam. channel apertures (25-100 Å) has greatly expanded the capabilities of heterogeneous catalysis. The large apertures in such mesoporous silicas can, for example, by modified by framework substitution to create highly selective catalysts. Here we show that direct grafting of an organometallic complex onto the inner walls of mesoporous silica MCM-41 generates a shape-selective catalyst with a large concn. of accessible, well spaced and structurally well defined active sites. Specifically, attachment of a titanocene-derived catalyst precursor to the pore walls of MCM-41 produces a catalyst for the epoxidn. of cyclohexene and more bulky cyclic alkenes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXptlSmt7Y%253D&md5=0e9a94183b9378aef38a3bb20c2b8913
        (k) Bu, X.; Feng, P.; Stucky, G. D. J. Solid State Chem. 1997, 131, 387.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        A lamellar hydrated barium cobalt phosphate with a two-dimensional array of Co-O-Co network: Ba(CoPO4)2·H2O
        Bu, Xianhui; Feng, Pingyun; Stucky, Galen D.
        Journal of Solid State Chemistry (1997), 131 (2), 387-393CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Academic)
        The hydrothermal synthesis and x-ray crystal structure of a hydrated Ba Co phosphate are presented. The structure is built from Co octahedra edge-shared with P tetrahedra. Co polyhedra form corner-sharing chains along the crystallog. b axis. These chains are interconnected by H2O mols. and phosphate groups to form an infinite two-dimensional sheet. Sheets are stacked along the crystallog. c axis with charge balancing cations, Ba2+, located in the interlayer region. The structure also consists of two-dimensional arrays of Co-O-Co networks with Co centers forming hexagonal patterns. There are a limited no. of Co(II) phosphates in which the Co/P ratio is 1. A summary of these Co(II) phosphates is given. A classification scheme based on the extent of the Co-O-Co linkage is provided for Co phosphates. Crystal data for Ba(CoPO4)2·H2O, M = 463.16, space group C2, a 9.2494(4), b 4.9140(2), c 8.2650(4) Å, β 91.744(2)°, Z = 2, dc = 4.097 g cm-3, thin plate, MoKα, λ = 0.71073 Å, μ = 10.005 mm-1, 2θmax = 56.44°, R = 2.43% for 70 parameters and 908 reflections with I > 2σ(I).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXltFKlsrw%253D&md5=ce2de9f289fcb7e98e03db01824f2f44
        (l) Clearfield, A. Inorganic Ion Exchange Materials; Clearfield, A., Ed.; CRC Press:  Boca Raton, FL, 1991.

      2. 2
        (a) Kitagawa, S.; Kitaura, R. Comments Inorg. Chem.2002, 23, 101.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Pillared layer compounds based on metal complexes. Synthesis and properties towards porous materials
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo
        Comments on Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 23 (2), 101-126CODEN: COICDZ; ISSN:0260-3594. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        A review. Microporous materials have been studied extensively because of their useful properties such as gas adsorption, ion exchange, and heterogeneous catalysis. Pillared-layer structure is a representative of porous structural motifs. Not only the channel size and shape but also the chem. and phys. properties can be readily designed and realized by pillar modules. A large no. of pillared layer compds., mainly in inorg. and org.-inorg. hybrid compds., have been synthesized and characterized. On the other hand, pillared layer compds. based on coordination compds. are not common. New types of pillared layer compds., constructed from coordination compds., focusing on structure, properties, advantages and future prospects are described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XivFGrsb0%253D&md5=bde5a3e1209215d142f4855705f22ecb
        (b) Kitaura, R.; Fujimoto, K.; Noro, S.; Kondo, M.; Kitagawa, S. Angew. Chem.,Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 133.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        A pillared-layer coordination polymer network displaying hysteretic sorption: [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg)]n (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; dpyg = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)glycol)
        Kitaura, Ryo; Fujimoto, Kentaro; Noro, Shin-ichiro; Kondo, Mitsuru; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (1), 133-135CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg).8H2O]n (I) (H2pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid; dpyg = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)glycol) was prepd. by the reaction of C(ClO4)2 with Na2pzdc and dpyg in H2O/EtOH. I is monoclinic, space group P21/c, Z = 2, R = 0.071, Rw = 0.095. In I each Cu(II) is 5-coordinate, residing in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment, surrounded by 3 O atoms from 3 pzdc ligands and 2 N atoms from a dpyg and pzdc ligand. The Cu2(μ-O)2 units are linked together by the pzdc ligands to give a 2-dimensional layer in the bc plane. The dpyg ligand acts as a pillar. The thermal decompn. of I was studied. The adsorption isotherms of anhyd. [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg)]n (II) for CH4, H2O and MeOH to exam. the porous properties. II adsorbs MeOH and H2O; and the adsorption isotherms exhibit hysteretic behavior.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvFantQ%253D%253D&md5=b06f1a72f903d2f2aa3e5d093c026c6d
        (c) Barton, T. J.; Bull, L. M.; Klemperer, W. G.; Loy, D. A.; McEnaney, B.; Misono, M.; Monson, P. A.; Pez, G.; Scherer, G. W.; Vartuli, J. C.; Yaghi, O. M. Chem. Mater. 1999, 2633.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Tailored Porous Materials
        Barton, Thomas J.; Bull, Lucy M.; Klemperer, Walter G.; Loy, Douglas A.; McEnaney, Brian; Misono, Makoto; Monson, Peter A.; Pez, Guido; Scherer, George W.; Vartuli, James C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Chemistry of Materials (1999), 11 (10), 2633-2656CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 205 refs., is the product of a study panel convened under the auspices of the United States Department of Energy Council on Materials Research to assess the basic research needs and opportunities in the area of tailored porous materials. Tailoring of porous materials involves not only chem. synthetic techniques for tailoring microscopic properties such as pore size, pore shape, pore connectivity, and pore surface reactivity, but also materials processing techniques for tailoring the meso- and the macroscopic properties of bulk materials as fibers, thin films, and monoliths. These issues are addressed in the context of five specific classes of porous materials: oxide mol. sieves, porous coordination solids, porous carbons, sol-gel-derived oxides, and porous heteropolyanion salts. Reviews of these specific areas are preceded by a presentation of background material and review of current theor. approaches to adsorption phenomena. A concluding section outlines current research needs and opportunities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXms1Gkur8%253D&md5=d14eaaa7db367cfc92193dd1cdf60f43
        (d) O'Keeffe, M.; Eddaoudi, M.; Li, H.; Reineke, T.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Solid State Chem. 2000, 152, 3.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Frameworks for extended solids: geometrical design principles
        O'Keeffe, M.; Eddaoudi, M.; Li, Hailian; Reineke, T.; Yaghi, O. M.
        Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2000), 152 (1), 3-20CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Academic Press)
        A review, with 82 refs., is given on the basic topologies (nets) that underlie most low-d. (open) structures. The basic geometries for three-dimensional low-connectivity nets are described. Examples of open framework solids with these topologies are adduced for illustration. Attention is drawn to methods of producing open frameworks by decoration and expansion of simple nets. (c) 2000 Academic Press.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXksFyitr8%253D&md5=ee50f80f8c2c209c7de6027c16d36e33
        (e) Kitagawa, S.; Kondo, M. Bull. Chem. Soc. Jpn. 1998, 71, 1739.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Functional micropore chemistry of crystalline metal complex-assembled compounds
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kondo, Mitsuru
        Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan (1998), 71 (8), 1739-1753CODEN: BCSJA8; ISSN:0009-2673. (Chemical Society of Japan)
        A review with 108 refs. Syntheses of new porous frameworks with specific pore size and type are of considerable interest for the appearance of zeolite-like functionalities. It is useful to take advantage of metal complex-assembled compds. because of designable frameworks, high microporosity, and flexible frameworks based on a variety of coordination geometries of metal centers and multifunctionality of bridging org. parts. Many recent reports show that the synthesis procedures are developing from serendipitous to rational level. Therefore, the micropore chem. of metal complex-based assemblages is directed toward not only new frameworks but also functionalities such as gas and small mol. adsorption, ion exchange, heterogeneous catalysis, photo-chem. and -phys. properties. For chem. and phys. functionalities robustness of a framework is required even in the absence of guest mols. in the cavity. The stability is largely dependent on the structural dimensionality of the assemblages. A wide variety of structures of metal complex-based assemblages are listed and recent findings in this functional chem. are described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (f) Biradha, K.; Hongo, Y.; Fujita, M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 3395.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Crystal-to-crystal sliding of 2D coordination layers triggered by guest exchange
        Biradha, Kumar; Hongo, Yoshito; Fujita, Makoto
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (18), 3395-3398CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The crystal structure of [NiL2(NO3)2.3.5(o-xylene)], where L = 4,4'-bis(4-pyridyl)biphenyl, was detd in monoclinic space group C2/c and then reacted with mesitylene so that the o-xylene guest mols. were replaced with mesitylene to form {[NiL2(NO3)2.1.7(mesitylene)]n} and its crystal structure was detd. in monoclinic space group P2/c. A crystal-to-crystal sliding of a 2D network between two packing modes is triggered by the guest exchange of solvent mols., and results in considerable difference in the channel dimensions. {[NiL2(NO3)2.1.7(mesitylene)]n} can exchange mesitylene for many liq. arom. guest mols. without destroying or altering the crystal structure.

        Open network architectures from the self-assembly of AgNO3 and 5,10,15,20-tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin (H2tpyp) building blocks: The exceptional self-penetrating topology of the 3D network of [Ag8(ZnIItpyp)7(H2O)2](NO3)8
        Carlucci, Lucia; Ciani, Gianfranco; Proserpio, Davide M.; Porta, Francesca
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (3), 317-322CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Novel polymeric frameworks are prepd. from self-assembly of AgNO3 with 5,10,15,20-tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin (H2tpyp) or its zinc(II) complex, Zntpyp. Prepd. are 2D complexes [Ag4(H2tpyp)3](NO3)4·x(solvate) (1) and [Ag2(H2tpyp)(NO3)]·x(solvate) (2), and the 3D network [Ag8(ZnIItpyp)7(H2O)2](NO3)8·x(solvate) (3). X-ray crystal structure detns. reveal only compd. 2 contains one of the expected structural motifs (2D square-grid layers). Topologies of compds. 1 and 3 are unprecedented, the latter one being a rare case of a 3D self-penetrating net. The networks are thermally robust and exhibit large free voids full of removable guest solvent mols.

        Unprecedented seven- and eight-connected lanthanide coordination networks
        Long, De-Liang; Blake, Alexander J.; Champness, Neil R.; Wilson, Claire; Schroder, Martin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2001), 40 (13), 2444-2447CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        [LaL4](CF3SO3)3.4.2MeOH (I), [LaL4](BPh4)(ClO4)2.2.75MeOH (II) and [LaL4][Co(C2B9H11)2]3.0.5MeOH (III) were prepd. (L = 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide). I tetragonal, space group P‾4c2, Z = 12, R1 = 0.132, wR2 = 0.309. II is monoclinic, space group P21/n, Z = 4, R1 = 0.062, wR2 = 0.096. III is orthorhombic, space group P21212, Z = 2, R1 = 0.044, wR2 = 0.919. In I L ligands bridge to 8 neighboring La atoms, forming a 3-dimensional bcc., CsCl-like, framework structure. In II La centers have an 8-coordinate geometry forming an infinite structure, but each La atom is bridged to 7 nearest neighbors because a pair of L form double bridges. In III each La center is ligated by 8 L but is linked to only 6 nearest neighbors with 2 pairs of ligands giving double bridges. This affords a 6-connected NaCl-like 3-dimensional structure. The Eu and Ho analogs of III were prepd. and their crystal structures detd.

        2
        A homochiral metal-organic porous material for enantioselective separation and catalysis
        Seo, Jung Soo; Whang, Dongmok; Lee, Hyoyoung; Jun, Sung Im; Oh, Jinho; Jeon, Young Jin; Kim, Kimoon
        Nature (London) (2000), 404 (6781), 982-986CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A homochiral metal-org. porous material with a carboxylic group at one end and a pyridyl group at the other forming oxo-bridged trinuclear metal carboxylate units in a three-dimensional framework was prepd., that allows enantioselective inclusion of metal complexes in its pores and catalyzes transesterification reactions in an enantioselective manner. The enantiopure chiral building block was prepd. from D-tartaric acid and 4-aminopyridine; then reaction with Zn2+ produced a homochiral open-framework solid, D-POST-1. The enantiomorphic L-POST-1 was obtained from the enantiomer of the building block and Zn2+ under the same conditions. The pyridyl groups in POST-1 can be converted to N-methylpyridinium without any changes of the network structure; the anion can be reversibly exchanged with other anions, e.g., PF6-, I3-, p-toluenesulfonate, etc. The pore size of POST-1 materials is modulated by N-alkylation and is dependent on alkyl chain length. The pyridyl groups are responsible for the catalytic activity of the oxo-bridged trinuclear metal complexes, in e.g., transesterification of 2,4-dinitrophenyl acetate (NPA) with ethanol, which produced Et acetate in 77% yield, only in the presence of POST-1. Transesterification with bulkier alcs. occurs more slowly or not at all, suggesting that catalysis occurs mainly in the POST-1 channels. The catalytic activity of D- and L-POST-1 is enantioselective as obsd. in the transesterification of NPA with 1-phenyl-2-propanol, which produces the corresponding esters with about 88% enantiomeric excess in favor of the resp. enantiomer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Complexes with aromatic carboxylic acids. I. Synthesis and crystal structure of zinc pyromellitate heptahydrate
        Robl, Christian
        Zeitschrift fuer Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie (1987), 554 (), 79-86CODEN: ZAACAB; ISSN:0044-2313.
        Single crystals of Zn(H2O)5[ZnC6H2(COO)4].2H2O (I) were obtained by crystn. in aq. silica gel. The crystal structure of I (monoclinic P21/n, a 593.1(1), b 2359.1(3), c 1168.7(1) pm, β 96.42(1)°, Z = 4, R = 1.94%), comprises features of ion exchangers, layer-like, and zeolitic structures. Zn(1) is coordinated tetrahedrally by 4 O atoms of the carboxylate groups, thus forming folded [ZnC6H2(COO)4]n2n- layers to which Zn(2) is bound by 1 carboxylate O atom. The coordination sphere of Zn(2) is completed by 5 H2O mols. to yield a slightly distorted octahedron. Addnl. H2O is accommodated between the layers. The [ZnC6H2(COO)4]n2n- layers possess channel-like cavities extending along [100] which are filled by H2O mols. H bonding is an important feature of this crystal structure.

        Coordination Assemblies from a Pd(II)-Cornered Square Complex
        Fujita, Makoto; Tominaga, Masahide; Hori, Akiko; Therrien, Bruno
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (4), 369-378CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The [enPd(II)]2+ (en = ethylenediamine) unit has emerged as a versatile building block in mol. self-assembly. In particular, the 90° coordination angle of the metal was judiciously used in the design of new discrete two- and three-dimensional structures. The authors' last 15 years of work with the Pd(II)-cornered unit is summarized in this Account, from the spontaneous formation of a Pd4 square metal complex to a family of architectures such as cages, bowls, boxes, tubes, catenanes, and spheres.

        Chemistry and Physics of Supramolecular Magnetic Materials
        Kahn, Olivier
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2000), 33 (10), 647-657CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with 38 refs. The building of multidimensional magnetic materials obtained with the mol. precursor [Cu(opba)]2- is described. The reaction with other paramagnetic species (3d or 4f metal ions, org. radicals) yielded 1-dimensional, 2-dimensional, and interlocked networks. The magnetic properties of these systems are reviewed using polarized neutron diffraction and magnetic measurements. The spin d. maps give a precise description of the ground state of such mol. magnetic species. also, different long-range magnetic orderings (antiferro-, ferri-, and ferromagnetic) have been obtained.

        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.

      5. 5
        (a) Kurmoo, M.; Graham, A. W.; Day, P.; Coles, S. J.; Hursthouse, M. B.; Caulfield, J. L.; Singleton, J.; Pratt, F. L.; Hayes, W.; Ducasse, L.; Guioneeau, P. J. Am. Chem. Soc.1995, 117, 12209.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Superconducting and Semiconducting Magnetic Charge Transfer Salts: (BEDT-TTF)4AFe(C2O4)3·C6H5CN (A = H2O, K, NH4)
        Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Graham, Anthony W.; Day, Peter; Coles, Simon J.; Hursthouse, Michael B.; Caulfield, Jason L.; Singleton, John; Pratt, Francis L.; Hayes, William; et al.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1995), 117 (49), 12209-17CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Three new mol. charge transfer salts of bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF), (BEDT-TTF)4AFe(C2O4)3.C6H5CN (A = H2O, K, NH4), were prepd., and their crystal structures and phys. properties detd. The structures of all three salts consist of successive layers of BEDT-TTF and layers of approx. hexagonal geometry contg. alternating A and Fe(C2O4)33-, with C6H5CN lying within the hexagonal cavities. When A = K or NH4 the BEDT-TTF layers consist of dimers (BEDT-TTF)22+ sepd. by isolated (BEDT-TTF)0, the charge difference being estd. from the C:C and C-S bond lengths. These salts are semiconductors (σ ∼ 10-4 S cm-1, EA = 0.14 eV), and their magnetic susceptibilities are dominated by S = 5/2FeIII. The EPR spectra accordingly show only one sharp signal. When A = H2O the BEDT-TTF adopt the β'' packing, and the salt is a superconductor (Tc 7.0(3) K). The magnetic susceptibility above the crit. temp. is the sum of a Pauli component (2 × 10-3 emu mol-1) and a Curie-Weiss term. Below the transition the susceptibility depends on the field penetration according to the London penetration depth, increasing with increasing field until the crit. field. The Meissner effect is almost complete, indicating absence of pinning. The EPR spectra of the A = H2O compd. were characterized by two resonances, one of Dysonian shape due to the conduction electrons on the org. cations and the other of Lorentzian shape arising from the 3d electrons of FeIII. Electronic band structure calcns. suggest that the A = K compd. is semiconducting (Eg = 0.3 eV) in good agreement with that result obtained from elec. measurement and the A = H2O is metallic (W = 1.1 eV) with both electron and hole pockets in the Fermi surface. Optical reflectivity of the latter gives an electronic bandwidth of 1.0 eV, fully consistent with the band structure calcn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXpsFSitLk%253D&md5=8f5f3dd596fd3a8105bce5753394b746
        (b) Coronado, E.; Galan-Máscarós, J. R.; Gómez-García, C. J.; Laukhin, V. Nature2000, 408, 447.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Coexistence of ferromagnetism and metallic conductivity in a molecule-based layered compound
        Coronado, Eugenio; Galan-Mascaros, Jose R.; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.; Laukhin, Vladimir
        Nature (London) (2000), 408 (6811), 447-449CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Crystal engineering-the planning and construction of cryst. supramol. architectures from modular building blocks-permits the rational design of functional mol. materials that exhibit technol. useful behavior such as cond. and supercond., ferromagnetism and nonlinear optical properties. Because the presence of two cooperative properties in the same crystal lattice might result in new phys. phenomena and novel applications, a particularly attractive goal is the design of mol. materials with two properties that are difficult or impossible to combine in a conventional inorg. solid with a continuous lattice. A promising strategy for creating this type of "bi-functionality" targets hybrid org./inorg. crystals comprising two functional sub-lattices exhibiting distinct properties. In this way, the org. π-electron donor bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF) and its derivs., which form the basis of most known mol. conductors and superconductors, have been combined with mol. magnetic anions, yielding predominantly materials with conventional semiconducting or conducting properties, but also systems that are both superconducting and paramagnetic. But interesting bulk magnetic properties fail to develop, owing to the discrete nature of the inorg. anions. Another strategy for achieving cooperative magnetism involves insertion of functional bulky cations into a polymeric magnetic anion, such as the bimetallic oxalato complex [MnIICrIII(C2O4)3]-, but only insol. powders have been obtained in most cases. Here we report the synthesis of single crystals formed by infinite sheets of this magnetic coordination polymer interleaved with layers of conducting BEDT-TTF cations, and show that this mol.-based compd. displays ferromagnetism and metallic cond.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXos1Srsbg%253D&md5=95dde17fdfaa93e00969cd2e9b03d555
        (b) Day, P.; Kurmoo, M. J. Mater. Chem.1997, 7, 1291.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Molecular magnetic semiconductors, metals and superconductors: BEDT-TTF salts with magnetic anions
        Day, Peter; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (1997), 7 (8), 1291-1295CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Mol. charge-transfer salts that consist of alternating layers of org. donor mols. and inorg. anions offer the opportunity of bringing together in the same crystal lattice conduction electrons localized on the donor sublattice and magnetic moments localized on the inorg. anions. A wide range of such compds. is formed by the donor mol. BEDT-TTF [bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene]. Some are semiconductors, others are metals while one is a superconductor, the 1st contg. paramagnetic 3d moments. The structures, magnetic and cond. properties of examples from each category are reviewed with 29 refs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXls1Whurk%253D&md5=a6b8e5d5845aa4aa7a03050e7032492a
        (c) Fujiwara, H.; Kobayashi, H.; Fujiwara, E.; Kobayashi, A. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2002, 124, 6816.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        An Indication of Magnetic-Field-Induced Superconductivity in a Bifunctional Layered Organic Conductor, κ-(BETS)2FeBr4
        Fujiwara, Hideki; Kobayashi, Hayao; Fujiwara, Emiko; Kobayashi, Akiko
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (24), 6816-6817CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Hybrid systems consisting of the conducting layers of org. donor mols. and the magnetic layers of inorg. anions have been focused on as possible bifunctional materials, whose conducting properties can be tuned by controlling the magnetic state of the anion layers on an application of magnetic field. Here we report the magnetoresistance of the antiferromagnetic org. superconductor, κ-(BETS)2FeBr4 [BETS = bis(ethylenedithio)tetraselenafulvalene], consisting of the two-dimensional superconducting layers of the BETS semications and the insulating layers of the FeBr4- anions. Due to the metamagnetic nature of the Fe3+ spin system, characteristic resistivity decrease was obsd. just below the antiferromagnetic superconductor-to-ferromagnetic metal transition at 1.6 T. Furthermore, an indication of the onsets of the magnetic-field-induced supercond. was discovered around 12.5 T.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XjslensLk%253D&md5=1caf6001707590afd0c667d3f4d50492
        (d) Zhang, B.; Tanaka, H.; Fujiwara, H.; Kobayashi, H.; Fujiwara, E.; Kobayashi, A. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2002, 124, 9982.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Dual-Action Molecular Superconductors with Magnetic Anions
        Zhang, Bin; Tanaka, Hisashi; Fujiwara, Hideki; Kobayashi, Hayao; Fujiwara, Emiko; Kobayashi, Akiko
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (34), 9982-9983CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Dual-action org. superconductors, whose conducting properties can be sharply controlled by an external magnetic field, were discovered in systems consisting of org. conduction layers based on bis(ethylenedithio)tetraselenafulvalene (BETS) mols. and magnetic anions. Owing to the metamagnetic nature of the anion layers, the superconducting state of κ-BETS2FeBr4 can be switched on or off by applying the external field. In λ-BETS2Fe0.4Ga0.6Cl4, exhibiting a field-induced superconducting transition for the field parallel to the conduction plane, the insulating, metallic, and superconducting states can be realized in a stepwise manner by slightly tuning the external magnetic field.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xls1yqtbY%253D&md5=e38bb8074da7666e6cd0831f857620d5
        (e) Uji, S.; Shinagawa, H.; Terashima, T.; Yakabe, T.; Terai, Y.; Tokumoto, M.; Kobayashi, A.; Tanaka, H.; Kobayashi, H. Nature2001, 410, 908.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Magnetic-field-induced superconductivity in a two-dimensional organic conductor
        Uji, S.; Shinagawa, H.; Terashima, T.; Yakabe, T.; Terai, Y.; Tokumoto, M.; Kobayashi, A.; Tanaka, H,.; Kobayashi, H.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2001), 410 (6831), 908-910CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The application of a sufficiently strong magnetic field to a superconductor will, in general, destroy the superconducting state. Two mechanisms are responsible for this. The first is the Zeeman effect, which breaks apart the paired electrons if they are in a spin-singlet (but not a spin-triplet) state. The second is the so-called 'orbital' effect whereby the vortices penetrate into the superconductors and the energy gain due to the formation of the paired electrons is lost. For the case of layered, two-dimensional superconductors, such as the high-Tc copper oxides, the orbital effect is reduced when the applied magnetic field is parallel to the conducting layers. Here, the authors report resistance and magnetic-torque expts. on single crystals of the quasi-two-dimensional org. conductor λ-(BETS)2FeCl4, where BETS is bis(ethylenedithio)tetraselenafulvalene. The authors find that for magnetic fields applied exactly parallel to the conducting layers of the crystals, supercond. is induced for fields above 17 T at a temp. of 0.1 K. The resulting phase diagram indicates that the transition temp. increases with magnetic field, i.e., the superconducting state is further stabilized with magnetic field.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjt1Kktb8%253D&md5=0b84fb931612802c8a998a5a02246874
        (f) Sato, O. Acc. Chem. Res.2003, 36, 692.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Optically Switchable Molecular Solids: Photoinduced Spin-Crossover, Photochromism, and Photoinduced Magnetization
        Sato, Osamu
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2003), 36 (9), 692-700CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. A possible route to finding new optically switchable mol. solids is to investigate the photoeffects of compds. that exhibit an abrupt phase transition or hysteresis loop. Such compds. must possess at least bistable states that are sepd. by a potential barrier in free energy. On the basis of this idea the authors have recently succeeded in identifying three kinds of optically switchable mol. compds. These include an FeIII spin-crossover complex exhibiting light induced excited spin state trapping effects and a CuII photochromic complex and an FeCo Prussian blue exhibiting photoinduced magnetization. It should be noted that abrupt phase transitions or phase transitions with a hysteresis loop are obsd. when cooperativity due to an intermol. interaction operates within the crystals. This suggests that the introduction of intermol. interactions such as π-π interactions, hydrogen bonding, or an ion-dipole interaction might serve to achieve optical switching effects in mol. compds. A review.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXktVKrtbg%253D&md5=df1b227c48fbf77f5e13fb2334602cba
        (g) Sunatsuki, Y.; Ikuta, Y.; Matsumoto, N.; Ohta, H.; Kojima, M.; Iijima, S.; Hayami, S.; Maeda, Y.; Kaizaki, S.; Dahan, F.; Tuchagues, J. P. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2003, 42, 1614.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
