        An unprecedented homochiral mixed-valence spin-crossover compound
        Sunatsuki, Yukinari; Ikuta, Yuichi; Matsumoto, Naohide; Ohta, Hiromi; Kojima, Masaaki; Iijima, Seiichiro; Hayami, Shinya; Maeda, Yonezo; Kaizaki, Sumio; Dahan, Francoise; Tuchagues, Jean-Pierre
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (14), 1614-1618CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The homochiral mixed-valence complex [FeII(H3L)][FeIII(L)](NO3)2 (1, H3L = tris(2-(imidazol-4-ylmethyleneamino)ethyl)amine, I) was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog., IR, CD, ESR and Mossbauer spectroscopy, and magnetic susceptibility measurements. In 1 three independent properties are united, namely, mixed-valence states of iron metal centers, spin-crossover of the FeII and FeIII electronic structures, and homochiral assembly of the chiral [FeII(H3L)]2+ and [FeIII(L)] building blocks into a hydrogen-bonded supramol. structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXjtlyit7o%253D&md5=7519ba389d68142352e7345e3f9db82a
        (h) Lacroix, P. G.; Malfant, I.; Bénard, S.; Yu, P.; Rivière, E.; Nakatani, K. Chem. Mater.2001, 13, 441.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Hybrid Molecular-Based Magnets Containing Organic NLO Chromophores: A Search toward an Interplay between Magnetic and NLO Behavior
        Lacroix, Pascal G.; Malfant, Isabelle; Benard, Sophie; Yu, Pei; Riviere, Eric; Nakatani, Keitaro
        Chemistry of Materials (2001), 13 (2), 441-449CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A new hybrid mol.-based ferromagnet [(dmaph)PPh3][MnCr(ox)3] ([(dmaph)PPh3]+ = the (4-dimethylaminophenyl)triphenylphosphonium cation and ox2- = oxalate anion) was synthesized. It crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 space group, with a 13.954(2), b 16.297(2), c 14.323(2) Å, and β 99.27(1)°. Refinement based on Fo2 yields R = 0.072 and wR2 = 0.156. The compd. exhibits a ferromagnetic interaction between Cr3+ and Mn2+, with a long-range magnetic ordering at TC = 4.5 K. The hyperpolarizability (β) of the cation is calcd. within the framework of the INDO/SOS-based method, which indicates a β value comparable to that of p-nitroaniline for an absorption max. at 306 nm (εmax = 28,500 M-1 cm-1). This result is consistent with the observation of a SHG efficiency 4 times that of urea for the parent [(dmaph)PPh3]Br salt, at 1.907 μm. The noncentrosym. [(dmaph)PPh3][MnIICrIII(ox)3] deriv. was used as a model compd. for a study of the potential effect of a ferromagnetic ordering on the bulk NLO response of hybrid materials made of NLO cations inserted between magnetic anionic layers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXmsVertA%253D%253D&md5=789c2af6c15122a68393e2e59e9ecfe9
        (i) Barron, L. D.; Buckingham, A. D. Acc. Chem. Res.2001, 34, 781.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Time reversal and molecular properties
        Barron, Laurence D.; Buckingham, A. David
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (10), 781-789CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review discussing time reversal and mol. properties. Chemists regularly exploit point group symmetry in their analyses of mol. structure and properties but they rarely utilize time reversal symmetry. The time reversal operator T reverses the momenta and spins of all particles in a system and distinguishes properties which are even under T, such as the elec. dipole moment, from those that are odd, such as the magnetic dipole moment. We review the role of T in quantum mechanics and discuss its application to the properties of mols. in elec. and magnetic fields. Among the properties considered are natural and magnetic optical activity, magneto-chiral effects, antisym. Raman scattering, optical NMR and ESR, chirality, and abs. enantioselection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXntVygsLY%253D&md5=98625b7771d5225227b1661d02a314a6
        (j) Inoue, K.; Kikuchi, K.; Ohba, M.; Okawa, H. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2003, 42, 4810.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Structure and magnetic properties of a chiral two-dimensional ferrimagnet with TC of 38 K
        Inoue, Katsuya; Kikuchi, Koichi; Ohba, Masaaki; Okawa, Hisashi
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (39), 4810-4813CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The construction of mol.-based magnetic materials, which possess addnl. properties such as cond., photoreactivity, or optical properties, is discussed. The synthesis and crystal structure and optical and magnetic properties of a new 2D fully chiral ferrimagnet; [{Cr(CN)6}{Mn(S)-pnH(H2O)}](H2O), where [(S)-pn=(S)-1,2-diaminopropane], is described. X-ray structural anal. found an orthorhombic unit cell and the structure revealed the formation of a two-dimensional chiral network. The magnetic transition temp. at 38K was relatively high. Field cooled and zero field cooled susceptibility χmolT and magnetic moments were detd. The MCD spectra and Faraday effect was shown.

        Tetrathiafulvalene [FeIII(C2O4)Cl2]: An organic-inorganic hybrid exhibiting canted antiferromagnetism
        Zhang, Bin; Wang, Zheming; Fujiwara, Hideki; Kobayashi, Hayao; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Inoue, Katsuya; Mori, Takehiko; Gao, Song; Zhang, Yan; Zhu, Daoben
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (16), 1988-1991CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new org.-inorg. hybrid, (TTF+)FeIII(C2O4)Cl2, displaying canted antiferromagnetism was prepd. and characterized, where the tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) mols. are face-to-face dimers and the anion is a 1-dimensional coordination polymer (see Figure). Due to π-d interactions through short S···Cl and S···O contacts a three-dimensional Neel state is stabilized at the high temp. of 20 K.

        7
        Reversible Guest Exchange and Ferrimagnetism (TC = 60.5 K) in a Porous Cobalt(II)-Hydroxide Layer Structure Pillared with trans-1,4-Cyclohexanedicarboxylate
        Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Kumagai, Hitoshi; Hughes, Suzanne M.; Kepert, Cameron J.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (21), 6709-6722CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis, characterization, and reversible guest-exchange chem. of a new porous magnetic material that orders ferrimagnetically at 60.5 K are described. The material, Co5(OH)8(chdc)·4H2O (chdc = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate), contains tetrahedral-octahedral-tetrahedral Co(II)-hydroxide layers Co(oct)3Co(tet)2(OH)8 that are linked together by bis(unidentate) chdc pillars. Noncoordinated water mols. occupy 1-dimensional channels situated between the chdc pillars. The material remains monocryst. during dehydration from Co5(OH)8(chdc)·4H2O (CDCC·4H2O) to Co5(OH)8(chdc) (CDCC) via an intermediate Co5(OH)8(chdc)·2H2O (CDCC·2H2O) upon heating or evacuation. In-situ single crystal and powder x-ray diffraction analyses indicate that the interlayer spacing decreases in two steps, each corresponding to the loss of two water mols. per formula unit as detd. by TG. The single crystal structure of the fully dehydrated material, CDCC, has no void vol. due to a tilting of the pillars and 9% decrease of the interlayer spacing with water removal. Exposure of CDCC to air causes rapid rehydration of this material to CDCC·4H2O, as detd. by single crystal x-ray diffraction, powder x-ray diffraction, TG, and vibrational spectroscopy. Both the hydrated and dehydrated forms order magnetically <60.5 K. The susceptibility data are consistent with ferrimagnetic behavior, and the value of the satn. magnetization at 2 K (∼2 μB) is explained by a model of two sublattices, one comprising three octahedral cobalt atoms and another comprising two tetrahedral cobalt atoms. There is an enhanced 2-dimensional correlation within the layer at temps. just above the Curie temp., as seen by nonlinearity in the a.c. susceptibility data and remanence in the isothermal magnetization. The crossover from 2-dimensional to 3-dimensional ordering occurs at TC. The large anisotropy in the magnetization data on a single crystal suggests either a 2-dimensional Ising or an XY magnet while the crit. exponent of 0.25 is in favor of the latter. Both magnetization data in a small field in the a.c. and d.c. mode and isothermal magnetization data provide evidence of a further change in behavior at 23 K, which may originate from a reorientation of the moments within the layer. Variation of the pillar and of the guest-exchange chem., including the exchange of magnetic guests such as O2, offers the possibility of tailoring the magnetic properties of this material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXnsFegsbw%253D&md5=7d2d5de766e0cfdaccd0c8a141002aa1
        (b) Rujiwatra, A.; Kepert, C. J.; Claridge, J. B.; Rosseinsky, M. J.; Kumagai, H.; Kurmoo, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2001, 123, 10584.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Layered Cobalt Hydroxysulfates with Both Rigid and Flexible Organic Pillars: Synthesis, Structure, Porosity, and Cooperative Magnetism
        Rujiwatra, Apinpus; Kepert, Cameron J.; Claridge, John B.; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.; Kumagai, Hitoshi; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (43), 10584-10594CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis and characterization of two members of a family of porous magnetic materials is described. The structures of Co4(SO4)(OH)6(en)0.5·3H2O and Co4(SO4)(OH)6(DABCO)0.5·H2O and their thermal stability can be tailored via the choice of org. pillar. The interactions between the pillaring agent and the compositionally complex inorg. layer are discussed. The influences of two pillaring agents i.e., the flexible ethylenediamine and the relatively rigid 1,4-diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane, on thermal stability, rigidity upon guest loss, and magnetic behavior of the pillared solids are compared. The magnetism of the pillared layered Co hydroxides is complex due to the influences of multiple metal sites, inter- and intralayer exchange, spin-orbit coupling, and geometrical frustration. The wide variety of potential pillars, oxyanions, and possible metal substitutions at the octahedral and tetrahedral sites offers the possibility of tailoring the magnetic and porous properties of these materials.

        Mn3(HCOO)6: a 3D porous magnet of diamond framework with nodes of Mn-centered MnMn4 tetrahedron and guest-modulated ordering temperature
        Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Bin; Fujiwara, Hideki; Kobayashi, Hayao; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2004), (4), 416-417CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Mn3(HCOO)6, a 3-dimensional highly stable and flexible porous diamondoid framework based on Mn-centered MnMn4 tetrahedral nodes, exhibits a wide spectrum of guest inclusion behavior and long-range magnetic ordering with guest-modulated crit. temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVaqs7k%253D&md5=eab8b639a850a3ecc7fbc15c732cc540

        8
        Synthesis and Characterization of a Porous Magnetic Diamond Framework, Co3(HCOO)6, and Its N2 Sorption Characteristic
        Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Bin; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Green, Mark A.; Fujiwara, Hideki; Otsuka, Takeo; Kobayashi, Hayao
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (5), 1230-1237CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        [Co3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) (1), the isostructural analog of the porous magnet of coordination framework [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O), and its desolvated form [Co3(HCOO)6] (2) were prepd. and characterized by x-ray and neutron diffraction methods, IR, thermal analyses, and BET, and their magnetic properties were measured. The parent compd. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c, a 11.254(2), b 9.832(1), c 18.108(3) Å, β 127.222(2)°, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0329 at 180 K. It possesses a unit cell vol. that is 9% smaller than [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) due to the smaller radius of Co2+ ion. Compared with the parent compd. 1, the desolvated compd. 2 has slightly larger lattice with cell parameters of a 11.2858(4), b 9.8690(4), c 18.1797(6) Å, β 127.193(2)°, V = 1613.0(1) Å3, R1 = 0.0356 at 180 K. The cell parameters of 2, obtained from neutron powder data at 2 K, are a 11.309(2), b 9.869(1), c 18.201(3) Å, β 127.244(8)°, V = 1617.3(5) Å3. The pore vol. reduces 33-30% by replacing Mn by Co. The material exhibits a diamond framework based on Co-centered CoCo4 tetrahedral nodes, in which all metal ions have octahedral coordination geometry and all HCOO groups link the metal ions in syn-syn/anti modes. It displays thermal stability up to 270°. The compd. easily loses guest mols. without loss of crystallinity, and it partly reabsorbs water from the atm. Significant N2 sorption was obsd. for the desolvated framework suggesting that the material possesses permanent porosity. The magnetic properties show a tendency to a 3-dimensional long-range magnetic ordering, probably antiferromagnetic with a spin canting arrangement <2 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1Omtb0%253D&md5=344dd2626388f9b496e3d05285ef8edf

        (a) Halder, G. J.; Kepert, C. J.; Moubaraki, B.; Murray, K. S.; Cashion, J. D. Science2002, 298, 1762.

        9
        Guest-Dependent Spin Crossover in a Nanoporous Molecular Framework Material
        Halder, Gregory J.; Kepert, Cameron J.; Moubaraki, Boujemaa; Murray, Keith S.; Cashion, John D.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 298 (5599), 1762-1765CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        The nanoporous metal-org. framework Fe2(azpy)4(NCS)4·(guest) (azpy is trans-4,4'-azopyridine) displays reversible uptake and release of guest mols. and contains electronic switching centers that are sensitive to the nature of the sorbed guests. The switching of this material arises from the presence of iron(II) spin crossover centers within the framework lattice, the sorbed phases undergoing "half-spin" crossovers, and the desorbed phase showing no switching property. The interpenetrated framework structure displays a considerable flexibility with guest uptake and release, causing substantial changes in the local geometry of the iron(II) centers. The generation of a host lattice that interacts with exchangeable guest species in a switchable fashion has implications for the generation of previously undeveloped advanced materials with applications in areas such as mol. sensing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XovFKmsrs%253D&md5=1a14d69e392744e88e9c20021c49107d
        (b) Maspoch, D.; Ruiz-Molina, D.; Wurst, K.; Domingo, N.; Cavallini, M.; Biscarini, F.; Tejada, J.; Rovira, C.; Veciana, J. Nat. Mater.2003, 2, 190.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        A nanoporous molecular magnet with reversible solvent-induced mechanical and magnetic properties
        Maspoch, Daniel; Ruiz-Molina, Daniel; Wurst, Klaus; Domingo, Neus; Cavallini, Massimilliano; Biscarini, Fabio; Tejada, Javier; Rovira, Concepcio; Veciana, Jaume
        Nature Materials (2003), 2 (3), 190-195CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Interest in metal-org. open-framework structures has increased enormously in the past few years because of the potential benefits of using crystal engineering techniques to yield nanoporous materials with predictable structures and interesting properties. Here the authors report a new efficient methodol. for the prepn. of metal-org. open-framework magnetic structures based on the use of a persistent org. free radical (PTMTC), functionalized with three carboxylic groups. Using this approach, the authors create an open-framework structure Cu3(PTMTC)2(py)6(CH3CH2OH)2(H2O), which the authors call MOROF-1, combining very large pores (2.8-3.1 nm) with bulk magnetic ordering. MOROF-1 shows a reversible and highly selective solvent-induced 'shrinking-breathing' process involving large vol. changes (25-35%) that strongly influence the magnetic properties of the material. This magnetic sponge-like behavior could be the 1st stage of a new route towards magnetic solvent sensors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Guillou Nathalie; Livage Carine; van Beek Wouter; Nogues Marc; Ferey Gerard

        9
        Co3[Co(CN)5]2: A Microporous Magnet with an Ordering Temperature of 38 K
        Beauvais, Laurance G.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (41), 12096-12097CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction between [Co(H2O)6]2+ and [Co(CN)5]3- in deoxygenated water yields a dark blue solid Co3[Co(CN)5]2·8H2O (1). X-ray powder diffraction data indicate a cubic Prussian blue-type framework, wherein the hexacyanometalate positions have only a 2/3 occupancy of square-pyramidal [Co(CN)5]3- units. Upon dehydration, the compd. retains crystallinity and exhibits a Type I dinitrogen sorption isotherm, characteristic of a microporous solid. Magnetic measurements show 1 to behave as a ferrimagnet with an ordering temp. of 48 K, which is reduced to 38 K in the dehydrated solid. At 5 K, both 1 and dehydrated 1 exhibit magnetic hysteresis with a coercive field of 1160 G (the highest value yet reported for a cubic Prussian blue analog) and remnant magnetizations of 1540 and 745 cm3G/mol, resp. Thus, dehydrated 1 represents the 1st compd. for which microporosity and long-range magnetic ordering coexist.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XntVKmsbY%253D&md5=1030c76b7184725f4b0aee5828a93962
        (e) Dybtsev, D. N.; Chun, H.; Yoon, S. H.; Kim, D.; Kim, K. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2004, 126, 32.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Microporous Manganese Formate: A Simple Metal-Organic Porous Material with High Framework Stability and Highly Selective Gas Sorption Properties
        Dybtsev, Danil N.; Chun, Hyungphil; Yoon, Sun Hong; Kim, Dongwoo; Kim, Kimoon
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (1), 32-33CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Novel microporous metal-org. framework material composed of Mn(II) and formate ions displays permanent porosity, high thermal stability, and size-selective gas sorption behavior. The framework is stable enough to maintain single crystallinity after the complete guest removal at 150 °C under a reduced pressure. Most importantly, it selectively adsorbs H2 and CO2 but not N2 and other gases with larger kinetic diams., which appears to be due to the small aperture of the channels. Despite a moderate H2 storage capacity, which is however still higher than that of any zeolite, its H2 surface coverage is one of the highest among the known microporous materials. Thus this new zeolite-like material made of a simple org. building block may find useful applications in gas sepn. and sensor.

        9
        Iron(II) formate [Fe(O2CH)2]·1/3HCO2H: a mesoporous magnet - solvothermal syntheses and crystal structures of the isomorphous framework metal(II) formates [M(O2CH)2]·n(solvent) (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mg)
        Viertelhaus, Martin; Adler, Peter; Clerac, Rodolphe; Anson, Christopher E.; Powell, Annie K.
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2005), (4), 692-703CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Recrystn. of iron(II) formate dihydrate from formic acid under solvothermal conditions results in single-crystals of the iron(II) formate, α-Fe(O2CH)2·0.33HCO2H. The crystal structure of this phase was detd. by x-ray diffraction and reveals an open framework structure with formic acid mols. occupying channels in the lattice which is stable even after removal of the solvent mols. Magnetic susceptibility and Mossbauer measurements show that the compd. undergoes 3-dimensional magnetic ordering below TC = 16 K. α-Fe(O2CH)2·0.33HCO2H and the corresponding magnesium, cobalt, nickel and zinc formates form an isomorphous series. In contrast to the iron compd., the magnetic behavior of the cobalt analog is dominated by antiferromagnetic interactions.

        Open-framework nickel succinate, [Ni7(C4H4O4)6(OH)2(H2O)2]·2H2O: a new hybrid material with three-dimensional Ni-O-Ni connectivity
        Forster, Paul M.; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (3), 457-459CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A cryst. open-framework nickel succinate , [Ni7L6(OH)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, was prepd. using a biphasic (cyclohexanol/water) system. The crystal structure was detd. showing the structure to consist of layers of edge-sharing NiO6 octahedra forming rings connected by isolated corner sharing NiO6 octahedra creating unidimensional pores lined by methylene groups of the succinate. The nickel succinate was further characterized by thermal anal. and magnetic susceptibility measurements.

        Copper complex with a magnetic ordering temperature above 400 K
        Yang, X. D.; Si, Lun; Ding, Jun; Ranford, John D.; Vittal, Jagadese J.
        Applied Physics Letters (2001), 78 (22), 3502-3504CODEN: APPLAB; ISSN:0003-6951. (American Institute of Physics)
        A monohydrated CuII dimer [Cu2(Sala)2(H2O)]n [H2Sala = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-L-alanine] exists as a coordination-helical polymer in the solid state. Thermal dehydration at 340-373 K converts this helical polymer to three-dimensional chiral network polymer, [Cu2(Sala)2]n. Both the hydrated and the anhyd. samples exhibit canted antiferromagnetism at room temp. A compensation temp. was obsd. at ∼20 K and The hydrated sample has a magnetic ordering temp. of 300 K, while the anhyd. structure possessed a magnetic ordering temp. ≤435 K.

        Thermal conversion of a helical coil into a three-dimensional chiral framework
        Ranford, John D.; Vittal, Jagadese J.; Wu, Daqing; Yang, Xiandong
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1999), 38 (23), 3498-3501CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)

[{Cu(sala)}n] (3), where the basic structure has remained intact but now a porous, 3D network coordination polymer has been established. This demonstrates for the first time the conversion of 1D helical strands into a chiral framework structure. This appears to be the 1st example of a true "solid-state supramol. synthesis.". 1 And 3 were both characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction anal.

        Cooperative magnetic behavior in the coordination polymers [Cu3(TMA)2L3] (L=H2O, pyridine)
        Zhang, Xi Xiang; Chui, Stephen S.-Y.; Williams, Ian D.
        Journal of Applied Physics (2000), 87 (9, Pt. 3), 6007-6009CODEN: JAPIAU; ISSN:0021-8979. (American Institute of Physics)
        The temp. and magnetic field dependent magnetization of the polymeric solids [Cu3(TMA)2L3], where TMA=benzene-1,3-5-tricarboxylate and L = H2O or pyridine were measured up to 5 T; These polymers contain dimeric [Cu2(O2CR)4] units. Discrete dimers in mols. such as cupric acetate have strong antiferromagnetic coupling between their two Cu d9 centers and at low T their susceptibility diminishes to nearly zero. While at higher T (300-100 K) the magnetism of the [Cu3(TMA)2L3] polymers resembles that of individual the [Cu2] dimer mols., at low T a new cooperative behavior is found, with a sharp increase in χ seen at temp. <75 K In the case of L = pyridine a plot of 1/χ vs. T shows linearity from 65 to 20 K and fits the Curie-Weiss law χ=C/(T- Θ ). Θ Is +4.7 K, indicative of a weak ferromagnetic coupling between dimers. This interaction may be facilitated by the planar arom. bridges between the [Cu2] units.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXjtFGksb4%253D&md5=b69b7f2b32fd4ac4bab0ebedd4eba380
        (k) Kahn, O.; Larionova, J.; Yakhmi, J. V. Chem.Eur. J. 1999, 5, 3443.

        9
        Molecular magnetic sponges
        Kahn, Olivier; Larionova, Joulia; Yakhmi, J. V.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (1999), 5 (12), 3443-3449CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A review with 22 refs. Some mol. magnetic materials behave as sponges. They can reversibly release or reabsorb H2O, both non-coordinated and coordinated, a process which is accompanied by a dramatic change of structure and of magnetic properties. When the sponges are hydrated, or wet, the structure consists of isolated units with a nonmagnetic ground state. When the sponges are dehydrated, or dry, the units are linked to each other, affording polymeric mol.-based magnets. Some of them exhibit a strong coercivity. [CoCu(obbz)].nH2O (obbz = N,N'-bis(2-carboxyphenyl)oxamido) represents a perfect example of such a situation. The starting material, [CoCu(obbz)(H2O)4].2H2O with a nonmagnetic ground state, has a zero-dimensional structure. The trihydrate behaves as a 1-dimensional ferrimagnet, and the monohydrate as a 2- or 3-dimensional ferrimagnet with a long-range magnetic ordering and a wide magnetic hysteresis loop. Upon rehydration, the tri- and monohydrates return to the initial hexahydrate form with a nonmagnetic ground state.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnvFKnu78%253D&md5=083ec8fcaa4c2607b6c00150ae0be1a6
        (l) Chavan, S. A.; Larionova, J.; Kahn, O.; Yakhmi, J. V. Philos. Mag. B:  Phys. Condens. Matter Stat. Mech. Electron. Opt. Magn. Prop.1998, 77, 1657.
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Magnetic behavior of the molecular sponge CoCu(pba)(H2O)3·2H2O, where pba = 1,3-propylenebis(oxamato)
        Chavan, S. A.; Larionova, Joulia; Kahn, Olivier; Yakhmi, J. V.
        Philosophical Magazine B: Physics of Condensed Matter: Statistical Mechanics, Electronic, Optical and Magnetic Properties (1998), 77 (6), 1657-1668CODEN: PMABDJ; ISSN:0958-6644. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        The authors report the synthesis of the magnetic mol. compd. CoCu(pba)(H2O)3·2H2O, where pba = 1,3-propylenebis(oxamato). which is blue in color. Its χMT against T behavior suggests antiferromagnetic correlations between the Co(II)Cu(II)-based ferrimagnetic chains .ltorsim.7 K. Heating this compd. at 130°C in vacuum yields the dehydrated purple compd. CoCu(pba)·1H2O, which exhibits a transition to the bulk ferromagnetic state at ∼33 K, as confirmed by the d.c. and a.c. susceptibility measurements. The dehydrated compd. is a relatively hard mol. magnet showing a coercive field of 0.3 T at 5 K. The most interesting aspect is its 'sponge'-like characteristics, that is a complete reversibility of the magnetic properties. as well as the color change, under a simple dehydration rehydration process.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXjslOjtrY%253D&md5=ef4a098676328fd72c9b85b56e199842
        (m) Larionova, J.; Chavan, S. A.; Yakhmi, J. V.; Froystein, A. G.; Sletten, J.; Sourisseau, C.; Kahn, O. Inorg. Chem.1997, 36, 6374.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Dramatic Modifications of Magnetic Properties through Dehydration-Rehydration Processes of the Molecular Magnetic Sponges CoCu(obbz)(H2O)4·2H2O and CoCu(obze)(H2O)4·2H2O, with obbz = N,N'-Bis(2-carboxyphenyl)oxamido and obze = N-(2-Carboxyphenyl)-N'-(carboxymethyl)oxamido
        Larionova, Joulia; Chavan, Suvarna A.; Yakhmi, J. V.; Froystein, Anne Gulbrandsen; Sletten, Jorunn; Sourisseau, Claude; Kahn, Olivier
        Inorganic Chemistry (1997), 36 (27), 6374-6381CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        CoCu(obbz)(H2O)4·2H2O (I) and CoCu(obze)(H2O)4·2H2O (II) were synthesized, and their crystal structures were detd. at room temp. Both crystallize in the monoclinic system, space group P21/n. The lattice parameters are a 7.8190(6), b 12.534(2), c 20.2770(10) Å, β 97.306(6)°, and Z = 4 for I and a 17.966(5), b 6.907(1), c 13.678(3) Å, β 97.69(1)°, and Z = 4 for II. For both compds., the structure consists of isolated Co2+Cu2+ pairs (in which the metal ions are bridged by an oxamide group) and noncoordinated H2O mols. A TGA was carried out. Three H2O mols. are removed at a temp. T2 (96° for I and 120° for II), and another 2 H2O mols. are removed at a temp. T3 (205° for I and 190° for II). When cooling down, the two compds. reabsorb H2O slowly and then return to the initial state. The dehydration-rehydration process is totally reversible, provided that the temp. does not exceed 275°. The magnetic properties of the starting materials, as well as the materials contg. three H2O mols. and then one, were studied, both in the d.c. and a.c. modes. I and II starting materials possess a nonmagnetic ground state. CoCu(obbz)(H2O)3 and CoCu(obze)(H2O)3 behave as 1-dimensional ferrimagnets without long-range magnetic ordering down to 2 K. CoCu(obbz)(H2O) and CoCu(obze)(H2O), finally, also behave as ferrimagnets, but with a long-range magnetic ordering occurring at 25 and 20 K, resp. Upon rehydration, the compds. return to the initial state with a nonmagnetic ground state. IR and Raman vibrational spectroscopies were used to obtain further insights into the structural modifications accompanying the removal and the uptake of H2O mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXjtl2h&md5=efce58f04def210a7fe55e5589c8c55c
        (n) Nakatani, K.; Bergerat, P.; Codjovi, E.; Mathoniere, C.; Yu, P.; Kahn, O. Inorg. Chem.1991, 30, 3977.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Optimization of a molecular-based [manganese copper] magnet: MnCu(pbaOH)(H2O)2 (pbaOH = 2-hydroxy-1,3-propylenebis(oxamato)) with Tc = 30 K
        Nakatani, Keitaro; Bergerat, Pierre; Codjovi, Epiphane; Mathoniere, Corine; Pei, Yu; Kahn, Olivier
        Inorganic Chemistry (1991), 30 (21), 3977-8CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669.
        The compd. MnCu(pbaOH)(H2O)3 consisting of alternating bimetallic chains shows a spontaneous magnetization below Tc = 4.6 K. An attempt to shift Tc toward higher temps. is described. Warming MnCu(pbaOH)(H2O)3 in the solid phase at 100° under vacuum yields MnCu(pbaOH)(H2O)2. Electronic spectroscopy indicates that the water mol. removed belonged to the Cu(II) coordination sphere. Magnetic susceptibility and magnetization measurements on the partially dehydrated phase reveal a ferromagnetic transition at Tc = 30 K. Through very mild thermal treatment Tc was shifted from 4.6 to 30 K. This result is tentatively attributed to the fact that in MnCu(pbaOH)(H2O)2 the chains are closer to each others than in the starting material.

        Hybrid Inorganic-Organic Solids: An Emerging Class of Nanoporous Catalysts
        Forster, Paul M.; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Topics in Catalysis (2003), 24 (1-4), 79-86CODEN: TOCAFI; ISSN:1022-5528. (Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers)
        A review; nanoporous hybrid materials, both metal-org. coordination polymers and hybrid metal oxides, have recently developed into an important new class of solid-state compds. Potential applications in the field of heterogeneous catalysis include acid, shape-selective, chiral, ship-in-a-bottle, and shape-recognition-driven reactions. Here, we summarize the synthesis, structural features, chem. functionality, and catalytic properties of this unique family of materials.

        (a) Kurmoo, M. Chem. Mater.1999, 11, 3370.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Hard Magnets Based on Layered Cobalt Hydroxide: The Importance of Dipolar Interaction for Long-Range Magnetic Ordering
        Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Chemistry of Materials (1999), 11 (11), 3370-3378CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis of Co5(OH)8(C7H15CO2)2.4H2O, Co5(OH)8(O2CC6H12CO2).5H2O, Co5(OH)8(C12H25SO4)2.(3H2O.2NH3), and Co5(OH)8(C2N3)2.6H2O, their characterization by electron microscopy, XRD, TGA, IR, UV-visible, and XANES, and their magnetic properties are reported. They belong to a family of layered compds. having a triangular magnetic lattice. The basal spacing is 22.8, 16.2, 25.0, and 11.5 Å for the carboxylate, dicarboxylate, sulfate, and cyanide, resp. From the powder x-ray and crystal electron diffraction data, the compds. are inferred to adopt the structure of the monoclinic form of Zn5(OH)8X2.solvent. XANES confirms that only divalent Co is present in the compds. and visible absorption spectra display bands originating from both octahedral and tetrahedral coordinated CoII and none from CoIII. The magnetic data show that all the compds. behave as 2 sublattice ferrimagnets which are characterized by a min. in the temp. dependence of the moments and long-range ordering obsd. by spontaneous magnetization in small d.c. applied field, out-of-phase components in the a.c. magnetization and hysteresis loop. The satn. magnetization, approaching 3 μB at 2 K in field of 5 T, is in good agreement with the proposed structure consisting of 3 CoII in octahedral coordination in one sublattice and 2 CoII in tetrahedral coordination for the other. The Curie temp. attains 58 K and coercive field approaches 12,000 Oe at 2 K. The long-range ordering is driven by dipolar interaction between layers which have large effective moment resulting from short-range intralayer interactions. Interestingly, the Curie temps. are independent of the chem. and phys. nature of the anions, as expected for the proposed dipolar mechanism. The large coercive fields result from the synergy of cryst. shape and single ion anisotropies and to the alignment of the moments perpendicular to the layers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXmvVSlsbY%253D&md5=92a140364beaa0b8a24a68e5e3035791
        (b) Richard-Plouet, M.; Vilminot, S.; Guillot, M.; Kurmoo, M. Chem.Mater.2002, 14, 3829.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Canted Antiferromagnetism in an Organo-modified Layered Nickel Phyllosilicate
        Richard-Plouet, Mireille; Vilminot, Serge; Guillot, Murielle; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Chemistry of Materials (2002), 14 (9), 3829-3836CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal reaction of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) and Ni acetate tetrahydrate at 170° results in a layered Ni silicate, Ni3Si(C3H6NH3)F0.65O1.9(OH)4.45(CH3COO)1.1·xH2O, x = 0.38, with an interlayer spacing of 21 Å. The mol. structure is deduced from powder x-ray diffraction, TEM, x-ray absorption and IR spectroscopies, and a structure is proposed. Crystallog. data and at. coordinates are given. The structure consists of edge-sharing Ni(O,OH)6 layers sepd. by aminopropyl silicate and acetate. The magnetic behavior is described by layers of ferromagnetically coupled Ni ions (C = 1.28 emu K mol-1 and θ = +35 K) coupled antiferromagnetically at a Neel temp. of 21 K. A small spontaneous magnetization is obsd. due to canting of the sublattice magnetizations amounting to 0.7°. Isothermal magnetization measurements at 2 K on oriented samples reveal that the easy axis is perpendicular to the layers and a spin-flop field is obsd. at 20 kOe.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvFSmt7Y%253D&md5=2f55985db40180e9648821f62119b8ef
        (c) Kurmoo, M. J. Mater. Chem.1999, 9, 2595.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Ferrimagnetism in dicarboxylate-bridged cobalt hydroxide layers
        Kurmoo, M.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (1999), 9 (10), 2595-2598CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The synthesis, characterization (XRD, DTA, IR, UV-visible) and magnetic properties of the layered compd. Co5(OH)8(O2CC4H8CO2)·5H2O are reported. It is characterized by a triangular magnetic lattice with a metal-metal distance of 3.1 Å and an interlayer distance of 14.3 Å. The layers are bridged through the carboxylate groups of the adipate anions. Long range ferrimagnetic (three octahedrally coordinated Co centers with spin and two tetrahedrally coordinated Co centers with spin) ordering is characterized by spontaneous magnetization, an out-of-phase component in the a.c. susceptibility and a hysteresis loop. The Curie temp. is 52 K and the coercive field is 11,200 Oe at 2 K. Complete reversal of moment to the expected satn. of 3 B was not obsd. due to the large anisotropy field. The long range ordering does not depend on whether the layers are covalently linked confirming, therefore, the importance of dipolar interaction between layers having large effective moments as a consequence of short range intralayer interactions. The large coercive field is due to perpendicular alignment of the moment with respect to the layers and the synergy of cryst. shape and single ion anisotropies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXmsVGmtrs%253D&md5=7cb27d121492ec33c0be119344c5a81c
      12. 12
        (a) De'Bell, K.; MacIsaac, A. B.; Whitehead, J. P. Rev. Mod. Phys.2000, 72, 225.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Dipolar effects in magnetic thin films and quasi-two-dimensional systems
        De'Bell, K.; Maclsaac, A. B.; Whitehead, J. P.
        Reviews of Modern Physics (2000), 72 (1), 225-257CODEN: RMPHAT; ISSN:0034-6861. (American Physical Society)
        A review with many refs. Thin films and quasi-two-dimensional systems show a wide range of ordering effects and related pattern-formation phenomena. The origins of these phenomena can often be traced to competition between the at. (or mol.) interactions in the system and the resulting inherent frustration of the system. In magnetic thin films, a wide range of magnetic structures are possible as a result of the competition between the long-ranged dipolar interactions and localized interactions. This article reviews recent exptl. and theor. work which has developed the authors' understanding of ordering and pattern formation in these films and in related structures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXhvVOns7c%253D&md5=2f7f8ec681bb7bad8269ff9699a9028c
      13. 13
        (a) James, S. L. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2003, 32, 276.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Metal-organic frameworks
        James, Stuart L.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2003), 32 (5), 276-288CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks are a recently-identified class of porous polymeric material, consisting of metal ions linked together by org. bridging ligands, and are a new development on the interface between mol. coordination chem. and materials science. A range of novel structures was prepd. which feature amongst the largest pores known for cryst. compds., very high sorption capacities and complex sorption behavior not seen in aluminosilicate zeolites. The development of synthetic approaches to these materials and studies of their properties are reviewed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXmtFOltLY%253D&md5=e9e83de0580c0b7dc9929ea3594efe12
        (b) Janiak, C. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans.2003, 2781.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (c) Janiak, C. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans.2000, 3885.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.

        (a) Kepert, C. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000, 122, 5158.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        A Versatile Family of Interconvertible Microporous Chiral Molecular Frameworks: The First Example of Ligand Control of Network Chirality
        Kepert, C. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2000), 122 (21), 5158-5168CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two families of mol. frameworks which grow as homochiral single crystals are described. Both consist of multiple interpenetration of the three-connected chiral (10,3)-a (Y*) network and result from the tridentate coordination of the 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (btc) ligand to octahedral metal centers which act as linear connectors. The nature of the interpenetration is controlled by the auxiliary ligands bound in the equatorial plane of the metal center. Ethylene glycol (eg) binds in a unidentate fashion to form phase A which has 28% accessible solvent vol. and contains four interpenetrating (10,3)-a networks. 1,2-Propanediol (1,2-pd) coordinates as a bidentate ligand to yield a phase B with a greatly enhanced 51% of solvent accessible vol., because only two (distorted) (10,3)-a' networks interpenetrate. Ligands in the void space and bound to the metal center can both be liberated thermally: the kinetics of this process gave microporous desolvated cryst. A and B. The porous phases lose crystallinity reversibly upon further loss of ligands bound to the equatorial metal: crystallinity is restored upon exposure to the vapors of simple alcs., which can also effect conversion of B to A. Both phases present interpenetrating network topologies that are unique to chem. and adopt space groups that are new for mol. solids: A crystallizes in P4232 and B adopts I4132. B can be grown homochirally from enantiomerically pure diol template. The stereochem. of the alc. bound to the metal controls the helicity of the chiral framework. The structure detn. of the 1,2-propanediol phase represents the 1st demonstration that chiral mols. can specifically template helix handedness in a chiral porous framework solid.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXjtFKht7k%253D&md5=6e8e495fcee2e98cbe558c33273d52c1
        (b) Kepert, C. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J. J. Solid State Chem.2000, 152, 261.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Hydrogen bond-directed hexagonal frameworks based on coordinated 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate
        Kepert, C. J.; Prior, T. J.; Rosseinsky, M. J.
        Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2000), 152 (1), 261-270CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Academic Press)
        The authors report the prepn. and crystal structures of two phases contg. the hexagonal (6,3) network of the graphene sheet derived by tridentate coordination of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (btc) to octahedral NiII centers, giving solvated [Ni3(btc)2(py)9(H2O)3] and [Ni3(btc)2(py)6(BuOH)6]. When the solvent used is 2-methyl-1-butanol, water directs the coordination about NiII and ABCA'B'C' stacking of layers was obtained. The use of 1-butanol as solvent gives a different hydrogen-bonding arrangement around NiII and produces AAA stacking of the layers. The authors have previously demonstrated that the use of other alcs. such as methanol, ethanol, 1,2-ethanediol, and 1,2-propanediol gives 3-dimensional architectures. A change in the hydrogen bonding around the metal center leads to 2-dimensional structures which house substantial solvent-filled microcavities. The comparatively weak interactions between layers, and the relative importance of framework-solvent interactions, facilitates slippage of the hexagonal sheets and interconversion between stacking type with guest exchange. (c) 2000 Academic Press.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Chu, De-Qing; Xu, Ji-Qing; Duan, Li-Mei; Wang, Tie-Gang; Tang, Ao-Qing; Ye, Ling

        Construction of a new open-framework solid from 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate and zinc(II) building blocks
        Yaghi, Omar M.; Jernigan, Ryan; Li, Hailian; Davis, Charles E.; Groy, Thomas L.
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1997), (14), 2383-2384CODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Addn. copolymn. of cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate (CTC) with Zn(II) at 25° yielded the extended coordination solid, Zn3[(CTC)(C5H5N)]2·2Me2NC(O)H, which has 1-dimensional channels with an aperture of nearly 6 Å as found by an x-ray crystallog. study. Crystal data are reported in space group P21/c (R = 0.0617).

        The hydrothermal reaction of Mn dichloride with the K salt of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid at 220° gives [Mn3{C6H3(CO2)3-1,3,5}2] which exhibits two pathways for antiferromagnetic coupling.

        Tetraaquabis(3,5-dicarboxybenzoato-O)cobalt(II)
        Guillou, Nathalie; Livage, Carine; Marrot, Jerome; Ferey, Gerard
        Acta Crystallographica, Section C: Crystal Structure Communications (2000), C56 (12), 1427-1428CODEN: ACSCEE; ISSN:0108-2701. (Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.)
        The hydrothermal reaction of Co(II) chloride with trimesate (3,5-dicarboxybenzoate) ions in aq. soln. gives the novel title complex. Crystals of this complex are monoclinic, space group P21/c, with a 5.1160(1), b 13.0080(2), c 15.1890(1) Å, β 96.853(1)°; Z = 2, dc = 1.818; R = 0.025, Rw(F2) = 0.073 for 2590 reflections. The CoII ion lies on an inversion center and is octahedrally coordinated to two trimesate anions and four H2O mols. H bonds ensure the three-dimensional architecture of the structure.

        Construction of Two- and Three-Dimensional Coordination Polymers from Cobalt Trimesate
        Livage, Carine; Guillou, Nathalie; Marrot, Jerome; Ferey, Gerard
        Chemistry of Materials (2001), 13 (11), 4387-4392CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Two new Co 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (trimesic acid, TMA) coordination polymers were synthesized and structurally characterized:[Co3(H2O)6(TMA3-)(TMA2-)(TMA1-)]·2H2O (1) and K[Co3(TMA3-)(TMA2-)2]·5H2O (2). 1 Crystallizes in the hexagonal system, space group P6522, with a 16.7265(2), c 20.5822(4) Å, and dc = 1.889 g cm-3. 2 Is monoclinic, space group P2/c, with a 9.6096(1), b 12.5610(1), c 13.9736(2) Å, β 109.239(1)°, and dc = 1.938 g cm-3. 1 Is two-dimensional and formed by a dense stacking of {Co3(H2O)6(TMA3-)(TMA2-)(TMA1-)} layers. In compd. 2 the connection of sinusoidal chains of Co octahedra by two types of trimesate ions gives a three-dimensional network with pentahydrated channels.

        A chemically functionalizable nanoporous material [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n
        Chui, Stephen S.-Y.; Lo, Samuel M.-F.; Charmant, Jonathan P. H.; Orpen, A. Guy; Williams, Ian D.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1999), 283 (5405), 1148-1150CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Although zeolites and related materials combine nanoporosity with high thermal stability, they are difficult to modify or derivatize in a systematic way. A highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) was formed in 80% yield. It has interconnected [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (R is an arom. ring), which create a three-dimensional system of channels with a pore size of 1 nm and an accessible porosity of ∼40% in the solid. Unlike zeolites, the channel linings can be chem. functionalized; for example, the aqua ligands can be replaced by pyridines. TGA and high-temp. single-crystal diffractometry indicate that the framework is stable up to 240°.

        14
        Construction of Porous Solids from Hydrogen-Bonded Metal Complexes of 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic Acid
        Yaghi, O. M.; Li, Hailian; Groy, T. L.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1996), 118 (38), 9096-9101CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction of M(II) acetate hydrate (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) yields a material formulated as M3(BTC)2·12H2O. These compds. are isostructural as revealed by their XRPD patterns and a single crystal structure anal. performed on the Co contg. solid [monoclinic, space group C2, a 17.482(6) Å, b 12.963(5) Å, c 6.559(2) Å, β 112.04°, Z = 4]. This solid is composed of zigzag chains of tetra-aqua Co(II) benzenetricarboxylate that are H-bonded to yield a tightly held 3-dimensional network. Upon liberating 11 H2O ligands per formula unit a porous solid results, M3(BTC)2·H2O, which was found to reversibly and repeatedly bind H2O without destruction of the framework. The proposed 1-dimensional channels of the monohydrate have a pore diam. of 4 × 5 Å, which is typical of those obsd. in zeolites and mol. sieves. The successful inclusion of NH3 into the porous solid was demonstrated. Larger mols. and others without a reactive lone pair are disallowed from entering the channels.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmtF2it7o%253D&md5=34defce1376c6d1398533d64b3d4764b
        (o) Yaghi, O. M.; Davis, C. E.; Li, G.; Li, H. J. Am. Chem. Soc.1997, 119, 2861.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Selective Guest Binding by Tailored Channels in a 3-D Porous Zinc(II)-Benzenetricarboxylate Network
        Yaghi, O. M.; Davis, Charles E.; Li, Guangming; Li, Hailian
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1997), 119 (12), 2861-2868CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Diffusion of NEt3 into an EtOH soln. contg. 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) and Zn(II) nitrate hexahydrate yields cryst. Zn2(BTC)(NO3)·(H2O)(EtOH)5, which was formulated by elemental microanal., solid-state NMR, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction [cubic, space group P213, a 14.728(2) Å, Z = 4]. This compd. possesses a 3-dimensional structure with nearly 44% of the framework represented by an extended channel system having a 14 Å cross-section, where highly mobile EtOH and H2O guest mols. reside. The multidentate functionality of BTC imparts rigidity to the structure, consequently allowing the guests to be removed or exchanged without destruction of the porous framework. X-ray powder diffraction, solid-state NMR (13C CP-MAS and static), gas chromatog., and TG analyses reveal that this material is highly selective to alcs. because of the coordination environment adopted by Zn(II) within its framework. Other mol. inclusions such as THF, Me Et ketone, MeCN, and acetone are not permitted into the channels, due to the specific electronic demands of the Zn(II) center and its ability to direct the inclusion process even in cases where incoming mols. have the appropriate shape and size for inclusion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXitVGisb4%253D&md5=c341800daad9e85a27f80d84c63048ec
        (p) Michaelides, A.; Skoulika, S.; Kirtsis, V.; Raotopoulou, C.; Terzis, A. J. Chem. Res.1997, 204.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A self-assembling trinuclear molecular complex of nickel(II) with benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid
        Michaelides, Adonis; Skoulika, Stavroula; Kiritsis, Vangelis; Raptopoulou, Catherine; Terzis, Aris
        Journal of Chemical Research, Synopses (1997), (6), 204-205CODEN: JRPSDC; ISSN:0308-2342. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        [Ni3(trim)2(H2O)14]·4H2O (H3trim = trimesic acid), a self-complementary mol. organized in tapes using aqua ligands as H bond donors and carboxylate groups as H bond acceptors, was synthesized and the structure confirmed by x-ray crystallog. Crystal data are reported in space group P‾1, (R1 = 0.0249).

        15
        Construction of Hydrogen-Bonded and Coordination-Bonded Networks of Cobalt(II) with Pyromellitate: Synthesis, Structures, and Magnetic Properties
        Kumagai, Hitoshi; Kepert, Cameron J.; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (13), 3410-3422CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Synthesis (hydrothermal and metathesis), characterization (UV-visible, IR, TG/DTA), single-crystal x-ray structures, and magnetic properties of three Co(II)-pyromellitate complexes, purple [Co2(pm)]n (1), red [Co2(pm)(H2O)4]n·2nH2O (2), and pink [Co(H2O)6](H2pm) (3) (H4pm = pyromellitic acid (1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid)), are described. 1 Consists of 1-dimensional chains of edge-sharing CoO6 octahedra that are connected into layers via O-C-O bridges. The layers are held together by the pyromellitate (pm4-) backbone to give a three-dimensional structure with each ligand participating in an unprecedented 12 coordination bonds (Co-O) to 10 Co atoms. 2 Consists of a three-dimensional coordination network possessing cavities in which unbound H2O mols. reside. This highly sym. network comprises eight coordinate bonds (Co-O) between O atoms of pm4- to six trans-Co(H2O)2. 3 Possesses a H-bonded sandwich structure assocg. layers of [Co(H2O)6]2+ and planar H2pm2-. The IR spectra, reflecting the different coordination modes and charges of the pyromellitate, are presented and discussed. The magnetic properties of 1 indicate complex behavior with three ground states (collinear and canted antiferromagnetism and field-induced ferromagnetism). Above the Neel temp. (TN) of 16 K it displays paramagnetism with short-range ferromagnetic interactions (Θ = +16.4 K, μeff = 4.90 μB per Co). Below TN a weak spontaneous magnetization is obsd. at 12.8 K in low applied fields (H < 100 Oe). At higher fields (H > 1000 Oe) metamagnetic behavior is obsd. Two types of hysteresis loops are obsd.; one centered about zero field and the 2nd about the metamagnetic crit. field. The crit. field and the hysteresis width increase as the temp. is lowered. The heat capacity data suggest that 1 has a 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional magnetic lattice, and the derived magnetic entropy data confirm an anisotropic seff = 1/2 for the Co(II) ion. Magnetic susceptibility data indicate that 2 and 3 are paramagnets.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XktVaiurc%253D&md5=2eed48495ad4dc71ff2f7ea72f582402
      16. 16
        Kumagai, H.; Akita-Tanaka, M.; Inoue, K.; Kurmoo, M. J. Mater. Chem.2001, 11, 2146.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Hydrothermal synthesis and characterization of a new 3D-network containing the versatile cis,cis-cyclohexane-1,3,5-tricarboxylate
        Kumagai, Hitoshi; Akita-Tanaka, Motoko; Inoue, Katsuya; Kurmoo, Mohamedally
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2001), 11 (9), 2146-2151CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The hydrothermal synthesis, characterization, single crystal x-ray structures and magnetic properties of three-dimensional coordination polymers, [M3(CTC)2(μ-H2O)2(H2O)2]·5(H2O) [M = Co (1) Ni (2)], employing the flexible cis,cis-cyclohexane-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (CTC or C9H9O63-) are described. X-ray crystal structure analyses reveal that 1 and 2 are isostructural. They belong to the triclinic system, P‾1: a 7.799(2), b 9.212(1), c 10.784(2) Å, α 107.595(3), β 92.877(3), γ 110.248(3)°, V = 682.4(2) Å3 and Z = 2 for 1, and a 7.694(1), b 9.210(1), c 10.764(2) Å, α 108.598(3), β 92.300(3), γ 109.814(3)°, V = 670.6(2) Å3 and Z = 2 for 2. They consist of trinuclear motifs of pseudo-octahedral MO6 linked through μ-OH2 and μ-carboxylate to generate one-dimensional chains, which are further bridged by the tricarboxylate to form a non-interpenetrated three-dimensional network. The network possesses extended channels along all three crystallog. axes in which H2O mols. reside. Each carboxylate group displays a different coordination mode to the metals. The temp. dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities indicates dominant antiferromagnetic interaction within the trimer of the Co complex, tending towards a ferrimagnetic alignment at low temps., and mostly ferromagnetic interactions for the Ni complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      18. 18
        (a) Deacon, G. B.; Phillips, R. J. Coord. Chem. Rev. 1980, 33, 227.

        Relationships between the carbon-oxygen stretching frequencies of carboxylato complexes and the type of carboxylate coordination

        18
        Complexes of simple carboxylic acids
        Oldham, C.
        Progress in Inorganic Chemistry (1968), 10 (), 223-58CODEN: PIOCAR; ISSN:0079-6379.
        Carboxylate compds. are reviewed; since there is such a variety of monocarboxylic acids, HOAc is used as a basis. Significant differences from other carboxylates, where they exist, are indicated. Formate and acetate ions form many stable coordination complexes. Propionates and derivs. of higher acids show the same chem. characteristics as acetates except that as the C chain of the acid grows, the tendency to coordinate apparently decreases. An increasing no. of complexes have been shown to have a structure which, superficially at least, may be regarded as a replacement of the enolic H (such as occurs with β-diketones) to give a polymeric acetate bridge structure. To what extent this behavior is governed by the metal and what part the ligand plays is at present poorly understood. Structure and spectral properties are discussed. Compds. and complexes of Groups I, II, III, IV, V, VI, and IIB are discussed. 305 references.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF1cXltVamtLo%253D&md5=91fb117e982538fd8259b289b1525ef3
        (d) Doedens, R. J. Prog. Inorg. Chem.1976, 21, 209.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Supramolecular squares with Rh24+ corners
        Cotton, F. Albert; Daniels, Lee M.; Lin, Chun; Murillo, Carlos A.; Yu, Shu-Yan
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions (2001), (5), 502-504CODEN: JCSDAA; ISSN:1472-7773. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Six mol. squares were obtained by reacting the singly metal-metal-bonded complex [Rh2(cis-DAniF )2(CH3CNeq)4(CH3CNax)2](BF4)2 (DAniF = N,N'-di-p-anisylformamidinate), and (Et4N+)2(Carb2-) where Carb2- represents the dicarboxylate anion bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane-1,3-dicarboxylate, 1; tetrafluoroterephthalate, 2; 1,4-cubanedicarboxylate, 3; terephthalate, 4; fumarate, 5; trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate, 6. X-ray crystal structure studies were performed on the mol. squares contg. 1-4. These squares stack in the crystal forming square channels capable of accommodating solvent mols. The NMR spectra are consistent with the presence of highly sym. structures even in soln.

        19
        A New Type of Single-Helix Coordination Polymer with Mixed Ligands [M2(phen)2(e,a-cis-1,4-chdc)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co and Ni; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; chdc = cyclohexanedicarboxylate)
        Qi, Yanjuan; Wang, Yonghui; Hu, Changwen; Cao, Minhua; Mao, Li; Wang, Enbo
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (25), 8519-8523CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new family of single-stranded helical coordination polymers with mixed ligands, [M2(phen)2(e,a-cis-1,4-chdc)2(H2O)2]n (1, M = Co; 2, M = Ni; chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), were prepd. under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, TGA, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal. X-ray crystal structural analyses reveal that 1 and 2 are isomorphic and belong to the monoclinic system, space group P21/c; a 10.0566(5), b 8.8843(5), c 20.2912(14) Å, β 100.052(3)°, Z = 2 for 1; and a 9.8921(6), b 9.0151(4), c 20.1628(17) Å, β 100.31(2)°, Z = 2 for 2. In the structures of 1 and 2, the 1,4-chdc ligand possesses only one kind of e,a-cis-conformation although there are both cis- and trans-conformations in the raw material. Two oxygen atoms of one carboxyl in 1,4-chdc ligand and another oxygen atom of contraposition carboxyl link adjacent Co or Ni atoms into an infinite 1-dimensional zigzag chain. The most attractive structural feature of 1 and 2 is that they both exhibit an infinite chiral chainlike structure with 21 helixes along the b axis. The right-handed and the left-handed chains are alternate. Meanwhile, the adjacent chains of 1 and 2 are linked via hydrogen bonds into 2-dimensional network structures, which further form 3-dimensional frameworks via π-π interactions of 1,10-phen.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXoslKrurY%253D&md5=09b6391f60d326a36b14a7a00f2da909
        (d) Bi, W.; Cao, R.; Sun, D.; Yuan, D.; Li, X.; Wang, Y.; Li, X.; Hong, M. Chem. Commun.2004, 2104.

At pH 8.5 the cadmium complex with the trans isomer is preferred yielding [Cd4(trans-chdcH)2(trans-chdc)3(phen)4]·(trans-chdcH2)·6H2O (2). The crystal structures of 1 and 2 were detd.

        Two-dimensional CuII and first PbII coordination polymers based on a flexible 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate ligand displaying different conformations and coordination modes
        Du, Miao; Cai, Hua; Zhao, Xiao-Jun
        Inorganica Chimica Acta (2005), 358 (13), 4034-4038CODEN: ICHAA3; ISSN:0020-1693. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Two novel metal-org. hybrid coordination polymers {[Cu(bpo)(chdc)(H2O)](H2O)0.5}n (1) and [Pb(chdc)(H2O)]n (2) were synthesized under different conditions and structurally characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction technique, where H2chdc refers to a flexible 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid ligand and bpo is 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole. Complex 1 has a two-dimensional (2-D) grid-like [11.28 × 13.63 Å2] framework in which the CuII centers are extended via bidentate bridging ligands bpo and e,e-trans-chdc along two directions, exhibiting large porous cavities. Coordination polymer 2 represents the 1st PbII complex of H2chdc in which the larger PbII centers are connected by e,a-cis-chdc anions to afford a 2-dimensional close-knit structure.

        19
        Structural and magnetic properties of the phase transition in absorbed and non-absorbed copper(II) trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate
        Inoue, Mikako; Atake, Tooru; Kawaji, Hitoshi; Tojo, Takeo
        Solid State Communications (2005), 134 (5), 303-306CODEN: SSCOA4; ISSN:0038-1098. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A large amt. of toluene can be absorbed into the 1-dimensional tunnels in copper(II) trans-1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate (Cu(trans-1,4-OOCC6H10C)) at room temp., and it can be desorbed by evacuation at elevated temps. The reversible absorption/desorption behavior of toluene was studied by magnetic susceptibility measurements using SQUID magnetometer and by powder X-ray diffractometry with high-energy synchrotron radiation at SPring-8, Japan. The first order phase transition was obsd. at 160 K in the magnetic susceptibility curve for the empty (non-absorbed or desorbed) sample, and the structural difference between the low and high temp. phases was detected in the powder X-ray diffraction patterns. On the other hand, no phase transition was obsd. in fully toluene-absorbed sample, and the structure was similar to that of the low temp. phase of the empty sample. The absorption/desorption behavior obsd. in the present study coincides with the results of heat capacity measurements by adiabatic calorimetry reported previously.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXisFantbc%253D&md5=1fad5710fc0b185d082061456ba56606

        19
        Thermal studies on absorption/desorption of toluene in copper(II) trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate
        Inoue, Mikako; Moriwaki, Masato; Atake, Tooru; Kawaji, Hitoshi; Tojo, Takeo; Mori, Wasuke
        Chemical Physics Letters (2002), 365 (5,6), 509-513CODEN: CHPLBC; ISSN:0009-2614. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        Copper(II) trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate was synthesized, and the heat capacity was measured by adiabatic calorimetry between 13 and 300 K. A heat capacity anomaly due to the first-order phase transition was found at 160.0 K, and the enthalpy and entropy of transition were detd. to be 413.4 J mol-1 and 2.66 J K-1 mol-1, resp. The sample was found to absorb a large amt. of toluene, which was desorbed and re-absorbed reversibly. The reversibility of the absorption/desorption was confirmed by measurements of heat capacity; no phase transition was obsd. in the fully absorbed sample, but it reappeared in the desorbed sample. A sample that absorbed 11% toluene showed about a half size of the anomaly at 174 K in the heat capacity curve.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        19
        Synthesis and gas-occlusion properties of dinuclear molybdenum(II) dicarboxylates (fumarate, terephthalate, trans-trans-muconate, pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate, and trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate)
        Takamizawa, Satoshi; Mori, Wasuke; Furihata, Masatoshi; Takeda, Sadamu; Yamaguchi, Kizashi
        Inorganica Chimica Acta (1998), 283 (1), 268-274CODEN: ICHAA3; ISSN:0020-1693. (Elsevier Science S.A.)
        The bis-μ-dicarboxylate molybdenum(II) complexes Mo(II)2L2 (L = trans-O2C-CH:CH-CO2 (1), O2C-p-C6H4-CO2 (2), trans-trans-O2C-CH=CH-CH=CH-CO2 (3), 2,5-O2C-CH3N-CO2 (4, CH3N = pyridine), and trans-O2C-C6H10-CO2 (5, C6H10 = cyclohexane)) were prepd. and their gas-occlusion properties were characterized. The dinuclear complexes have quadruple Mo-Mo bonds, with the ground electronic configuration (σ)2(π)4(δ)2. All of these complexes are capable of occluding a large amt. of gas (1 or 2 mol of N2 gas per 1 mol of molybdenum atoms). Study of the structures of these complexes indicates that gases are most probably occluded in homogeneous and linear micropores which are composed of micropore units surrounded by four dicarboxylate bridges. 13C-CP/MAS NMR measurements indicate that gas mols. are held in the micropores created by the dicarboxylate ligands.

        (j) Cotton, F. A.; Lin, C.; Murillo, C. A. Acc. Chem. Res. 2001, 34, 759.

        19
        Supramolecular Arrays Based on Dimetal Building Units
        Cotton, F. Albert; Lin, Chun; Murillo, Carlos A.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (10), 759-771CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with refs. Supramol. chem. is today a major thrust area, a significant part of which is based on the use of metal atoms or ions as key elements in promoting the assembly of and dictating the main structural features of the supramol. products. Most of the work was done with single metal atoms or ions in this role, but considerable success has already been achieved by employing M-M bonded dimetal entities instead. The authors review here the work done in their lab. Metal-metal bonded cationic complexes of the [M2(DAniF)n(MeCN)8-2n](4-n)+ type, where M = Mo or Rh and DAniF is an N,N'-di-p-anisylformamidinate anion, were used as subunit precursors and then linked by various equatorial and axial bridging groups such as polycarboxylate anions, polypyridyls, and polynitriles. Characterization of the products by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, CV, DPV, NMR, and other spectroscopic techniques revealed discrete tetranuclear (pairs or loops), hexanuclear (triangles), octanuclear (squares), and dodecanuclear (cages) species and one-, two-, or three-dimensional mol. nanotubes. These compds. display a rich electrochem. behavior which is affected by the nature of the linkers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXlvFCrsLc%253D&md5=92c4e19e3eee08140954294be52bef23

        Kim, J.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T. M.; Li, H.; Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; O'Keefe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2001, 123, 8239.
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Assembly of Metal-Organic Frameworks from Large Organic and Inorganic Secondary Building Units: New Examples and Simplifying Principles for Complex Structures
        Kim, Jaheon; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (34), 8239-8247CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The secondary building unit (SBU) was identified as a useful tool in the anal. of complex metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The authors illustrate its applicability to rationalizing MOF crystal structures by anal. of nine new MOFs which were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Tetrahedral SBUs in Zn(ADC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-31; H2ADC = acetylenedicarboxylic acid; HTEA = monoprotonated triethylamine), Cd(ATC)·[Cd(H2O)6](H2O)5 (MOF-32; H4ATC = adamantanetetracarboxylic acid), and Zn2(ATB)(H2O)·(H2O)3(DMF)3 (MOF-33; H4ATB = adamantanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into diamond networks, while those of Ni2(ATC)(H2O)4·(H2O)4 (MOF-34) have the structure of the Al network in SrAl2. Frameworks constructed from less sym. tetrahedral SBUs have the Ga network of CaGa2O4 as illustrated by Zn2(ATC)·(EtOH)2(H2O)2 (MOF-35) structure. Squares and tetrahedral SBUs in Zn2(MTB)(H2O)2·(DMF)6(H2O)5 (MOF-36; H4MTB = methanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into the PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of these shapes. The octahedral SBUs found in Zn2(NDC)3·[(HTEA)(DEF)(ClBz)]2 (MOF-37; H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) form the most common structure for linking octahedral shapes, namely, the B network in CaB6. New structure types for linking triangular and trigonal prismatic SBUs are found in Zn3O(BTC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-38; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Zn3O(HBTB)2(H2O)·(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (MOF-39; H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid). The synthesis, crystal structure, and structure anal. using the SBU approach are presented for each MOF.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXls1Okt7w%253D&md5=b62be98fb09b7b7995390315da27c217
      22. 22
        Konar, S.; Mukherjee, P. S.; Zangrando, E.; Lloret, F.; Chaudhuri, N. R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2002, 41, 1561.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A three-dimensional homometallic molecular ferrimagnet
        Konar, Sanjit; Mukherjee, Partha Sarathi; Zangrando, Ennio; Lloret, Francesc; Chaudhuri, Nirmalendu Ray
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (9), 1561-1563CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Chains of fused NiII octahedral units form a 3-dimensional network and thereby the 1st example of a homometallic 3-dimensional ferrimagnet. [Ni3(fum)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]n (H2fum = fumaric acid) was prepd. from Na2fum and Ni(NO3)2 and characterized by x-ray anal. and a low-temp. magnetic study. The complex is monoclinic, space group P21/c, Z = 2, R = 0.0508, wR2 = 0.1383. The structure features an infinite - Ni-(μ3-OH)-Ni2- chain and the spin of adjacent Ni centers alternates between S = 1 and S = 2 (see picture).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XjvVGlu7w%253D&md5=12793463727097a3f711291c46d037ca
      23. 23
        (a) Kurmoo, M.; Kumagai, H.; Green, M. A.; Lovett, B. W.; Blundell, S. J.; Ardavan, A.; Singleton, J. J. Solid State Chem.2001, 159, 343.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Two Modifications of Layered Cobaltous Terephthalate: Crystal Structures and Magnetic Properties
        Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Kumagai, Hitoshi; Green, Mark A.; Lovett, Brendon W.; Blundell, Stephen J.; Ardavan, Arzhang; Singleton, John
        Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2001), 159 (2), 343-351CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Academic Press)
        The synthesis, characterization, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of Co2(OH)2BDC and Co(H2O)2BDC (BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate or terephthalate, O2CC6H4CO2) are reported. Co2(OH)2BDC (space group C2/m, a 19.952, b 3.286, c 6.295 Å, β 95.84°, Z = 2) consists of two types of edge-sharing CoO6 chains that are connected to each other by OH (Co-O-Co bridges) to form layers that are further joined together through terephthalate. It exhibits unusual magnetic properties: >48 K it displays paramagnetism, between 44 and 48 K it behaves as a collinear antiferromagnet, and <44 K a weak spontaneous magnetization is obsd. in very low applied fields. At higher fields metamagnetic behavior is obsd. Two types of hysteresis loops are obsd., one centered about zero field and the 2nd about the metamagnetic crit. field. The crit. field and the hysteresis width increase as the temp. is lowered; the latter exceeds 50 kOe at 2 K The unusual large coercivity may be due to the large single-ion anisotropy of Co(II) and its pronounced increase at low temp. Co(H2O)2BDC (space group C2/c, a 18.274, b 6.543, c 7.296 Å, β 98.6°, Z = 4) consists of layers of sepd. octahedral CoO6 connected via Co-O-C-O-Co. It is paramagnetic and obeys the Curie-Weiss law (Θ=-27 K). (c) 2001 Academic Press.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXkvVWnt7w%253D&md5=0c3bf42f5bd42ba32cc8098004fae1a2
        (b) Kurmoo, M. Philos. Trans. R. Soc., A1999, 357, 3041.
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Ferrimagnetic and metamagnetic layered cobalt(II)-hydroxides: first observation of a coercive field greater than 5 T
        Kurmoo, M.
        Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, Series A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences (1999), 357 (1762), 3041-3061CODEN: PTRMAD; ISSN:1364-503X. (Royal Society)
        The synthesis, characterization by XRD, UV-visible, IR and TGA and the magnetic properties of four layered compds., 1, Co5(OH)8(H2O)2(NO3)2; 2, Co5(OH)8(O2CC6H4CO2)·2H2O; 3, Co2(OH)3(NO3); 4, Co4(OH)2(O2CC6H4CO2)3·(NH 3)1.5(H2O)2.5, are reported. 1 And 2 were characterized by triple-deck layers consisting of both octahedral and tetrahedral cobaltous ions and 3 and 4 contain single-deck layers of only octahedral cobaltous ions. 1 And 2 behave as ferrimagnets which were characterized by a min. in the χT vs. T plot, spontaneous magnetization, imaginary AC-susceptibility and hysteresis loop. The Curie temp. are 30 and 40 K and the coercive fields at 4.2 K are 850 and 1750 Oe, resp. 3 And 4 behave as metamagnets which were characterized by maxima in the susceptibility at the Neel temp. of 10 and 38 K, resp., and by a crit. field (antiferromagnetic ↔ paramagnetic) of ca. 1 KOe for 3 at 4.5 K and >50 kOe for 4 at 2 K. The tricrit. temp., sepg. the region of reversible and nonreversible M vs. H, for 4 is established at 22.5 K. The long-range magnetic ordering for the two structural types is discussed from dipolar interactions between layers. The intralayer interactions are ferromagnetic in all cases whereas the interlayer interactions are ferromagnetic for 1 and 2 and antiferromagnetic for 3 and 4. The Curie or Neel temp. is weakly dependent on the interlayer distance and its observation does not depend on the existence of covalent bonds between the layers. The large coercive fields obsd. are due to the alignment of the moments perpendicular to the layers and the synergy between cryst. shape and single-ion anisotropies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXktVejtg%253D%253D&md5=29c6ff300e46f012505f472c27c4f2e8
      24. 24
        Rosi, N. L.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2002, 41, 284.
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Infinite secondary building units and forbidden catenation in metal-organic framework
        Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (2), 284-287CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        The metal-org. framework compds. MOF-69A, [Zn3(OH)2(bpdc)2]·4DEF·2H2O (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; DEF = N,N-diethylformamide), and MOF-69B, [Zn3(OH)2(ndc)2]·4DEF·2H2O (ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate), were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. Both MOF-69A and MOF-69B have three-dimensional structures constructed from infinite Zn-O-C secondary building units, which provide a framework in which catenation is forbidden. Both compds. contain one-dimensional rhombic channels in which the DEF and water mols. reside as guests. MOF-69A and MOF-69B are stable to exchange of guests in soln., and the process is fully reversible.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhtVyitr8%253D&md5=b7390361967b058ee6cd9710f2c27e9f
